column10: it was hard to play at first and i gave up for a long time but then I started to watch play troughs and they showed me what to do (I recommend jakeyosaurus) and after that I knew what to do and it got fun

So much customisation! The game I'm playing won't be the game you buy.

Excellent game with so many options, you can play a completely different game each time.

Let me start by saying I don't play games to use my brain. I play to turn it off. I want a relaxing experience, with just enough to think about to not just be a repetitive grind. Therefore, despite putting in 100+ hours, I haven't even begun to see all the game has to offer. I doubt I ever will.

I turn off most of the antagonists. I set everything to easy. I start with a lighter to make fire. I turn resource growth up high. I have Buffalos galore cos I need their poo! There are still some challenges - it's not like playing Minecraft on easy, there's more to it than that, but it isn't hard. I don't die. 

Minecraft is probably the closest comparison but without the building element and with some cool things, like going insane from lack of sleep and murderous ents!

If you want to play the game with everything turned on, it actually becomes really difficult. You have to strategise resource production carefully and you absolutely will die at some point, or your awesome camp will burn to the ground, essentially leaving you to start again. 

The Co op is good fun. I found myself playing alongside the other player rather than actually working together much... but it's nice to have company.

Progression is developing your camp and survival skills. That is where it falls down a little for me - and I accept this is probably just because of the way I play - but it takes a LONG time to get your camp to a point you can start to design it in any way. Once you have started to set down roots, which you need to do to at least some extent immediately because you can't carry everything around with you, it becomes incredibly hard to move your stuff. 

What this does offer, is a chance to go camping to explore! I find my expeditions around the map, carrying just what I need, are one of the things that I sink the most time into. And it's always nice to get back home again afterwards! Though do beware, unless your settings are all super easy, you may come home to find your camp destroyed.

Honestly, if any of this sounds appealing, go for it. It's different, it's good fun, and chances are you can find a way to customise it to your liking.

No matter how many times and how hard I tried to enjoy it, both Don't Starve games are not fun for me whatsoever. Despite playing them for over 11 years.

The game seems like a Terraria/Minecraft/Warframe-wannabe, in terms that it relies on a fanmade wiki, but unlike them it doesn't let you to chill, read wiki, and do what it says on practice right after. Time limit = Pressure, y'know?

I think way more people dislike Don't Starve than you see publicly, because it is... Another one of those "Untouchable" games, like Celeste, Baldur's Gate 3, Hollow Knight etc.

The Gorge was one of the best coop experiences I've ever had tho

[h1] Don’t Starve Together: A Survival Game That Will Keep You on Your Toes [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]

Challenging and rewarding gameplay that requires strategy, cooperation, and creativity
Beautiful and unique art style that creates a whimsical and dark atmosphere
Tons of content and variety, with different biomes, seasons, creatures, items, and events
Constant updates and support from the developers, with new features and improvements
Fun and hilarious multiplayer experience, with voice chat, emotes, and skins
[b] Cons: [/b]

Steep learning curve and unforgiving difficulty, especially for new players
Some bugs and glitches that can affect the performance and stability of the game
Potential griefing and trolling from other players, especially in public servers
High dependency on internet connection and server quality, which can cause lag and disconnects
[h2] Summary: [/h2]

Don’t Starve Together is a standalone multiplayer expansion of the wilderness survival game, Don’t Starve. It is a game that will test your skills, patience, and teamwork as you explore, fight, farm, and build in a harsh and mysterious world. The game is not for the faint of heart, as it will punish your mistakes and make you start over from scratch. However, it is also a game that will reward your efforts and achievements, as you discover new secrets and overcome new challenges. The game has a lot of depth and replay value, as it offers a lot of customization and randomness. The game also has a lot of charm and humor, as it features a quirky and distinctive art style, a witty and whimsical soundtrack, and a lively and diverse community. Don’t Starve Together is a game that will make you laugh, cry, rage, and rejoice, all in the same session. It is a game that will keep you on your toes, and keep you coming back for more.

It's an interesting take on the survival genre, I have spent quite a bit of time playing this and I can understand why people go for hundreds or thousands of hours on it.

Unlike most other games similar to this, you are very limited to what you can do to the world around you. Building is a weird and unfun experience.

The combat is also not good. You click some buttons on your keyboard, then step back so the creatures don't damage you. That's called kiting. It feels very unsatisfying to fight creatures on this game, it barely "feels" like your attacks are doing anything to the enemies. It makes for bland boss battles as you just keep spamming the same thing until their hp drops to zero and they poof out of existence. They are more of an annoyance than a fun fight you look forward to.

It's boring. there's not much to do and you'll constantly find yourself glued to a wiki page to figure out what content you can explore here. I'd look for something else.

If you suspect that your character, and the world generated has an "expiration date", you are correct. It's not good enough for Klei to be paid for the game, they must abuse you as well. How dare you want to be entertained? If you come up with a way to "farm" some valuable item, you're cheating, and your world will be deleted. (No, I don't play on "survival". I chose the "endless" world option.) It's how they keep you from realizing how bored you are--they make you angry! If you discover a way to manage a thing which is supposed to be threatening -like bees-forget it. Your world/server will be deleted. Don't buy it. They milk 1 good idea until it's not simply dead, it's resurrected, and sucking the life from you. If your computer is a fast one, then the animation moves fast enough that you can't really see that the antagonist isn't anywhere near you when it strikes. When your computer is slow, they paste over this by making your character glitch back and forth-while strangely none of the other animations are affected. If you savagely cheat this game to death, good on ya. You actually got to play it. The rest of us just got took.
Steam asked: "You've played an additional 100 hours. Would you like to revise your review? And yes, I would like enhance my comments. The art initially invites you in, permitting you to ignore little hints like the "meat effigy" and "lamb idol" that maybe you're not the intended audience for this game that plays you. It has cute little details like "Chester Esq", but completely smears over it with little ways of bringing you down. If you could actually progress through the game to the next level or event, it might color over these..."flaws"...but you can't, so after investing hours for the big moment, (the end of the story, the battle, or some conclusion) you're left with the impression that you just visited a communist country, and managed to leave before anyone accused you of being a spy. Even a slot machine will eventually let you win-you know, something.

Ah yes[b] Don't Starve Together[/b] the reason i haven't slept half of the time, it's pretty complex for a game as simple as rerolling every time you mess up. Now the main gameplay loop isint just that it consists of other gameplay element and stages of the game but im too lazy to actualy talk about theese so i'l go the fast route and just say why [b]I[/b] recomend the game.

It isin't much of a suprise that I like the game, i mean look at that hour count, so i'l start with...

[h2] The Good[/h2] aka. the "YEEE"

The game's dificulty provides a challenge for both new and experienced players, and the fact you are forced to do certain things to survive realy pushes that theme. It also has roots deeply connected to Don't Starve and has too much lore to even talk about. Have I even mentioned the skins? Yup you heard me right, this game has cosmetics and skins so you can flex, I am going to point out an issue with them later tough. lastly to close this off, it has server side mods, so only the server host has to have the mods. yes this makes a diferance.

you knew this was comming and you should have predicted it
[h2] The Bad[/h2] aka. The "WHYY"

Remember when I mentioned complaining about cosmetics? because there are limited edition ones! now dont get me wrong it feels great to have them but when youre a new player and you just missed egtting it... you are not going to be feeling the same. And remember when i talked about the dificulty? Yup if youre a new player there's a chance you will be looking for a tutorial. I'l be completley honest they had a good idea but managed to destroy it. another thing i have to talk about is hosting servers, it either runs perfectly or your server forgets what it is and just sais "nah" straight into your face, this is especialy true when you enable caves and mods... yeah the 2 of 4 pillars holding it [b]together[/b]. Lastly the main issue I have with this game is... well it gets boring pretty quick, like in the early game there isin't much hapening, like true it is imersive to a true survival situation, but spend a night in winter in this game, tell me is it realy that intresting?


[h2] THE CONCLUSION[/h2]

It pretty gud
The game has multiple ways of playing because of mods and modes ect. and the problems are kind of overshadowed by the good things. It's just good enough.  and let me know what you think, or if I made any mistakes in the comment section. just dont be rude or disrespect others!

Bit of a learning curve and takes quite a few hours to truly get into. This being said, it's thoroughly enjoyable with friends or alone. Though to note; playing with friends in other regions of the world there is a consistent issue with server delay and lag when performing actions. As an Australian playing with those in the United States, I find myself totally unable to combat enemies in game. There's something with the time it takes to swing at a monster, then attempt to kite their next attack, and the game's latency that makes it impossible to dodge. The actions happen before the animations, but mine occur late. I've heard that this is also an issue on the console version of the game, even when players are in the same region. On the same note, I am unable to enhance the speed of wood cutting and mining by spamming/holding the button, unlike my US mates. Something about the game feels slower when playing with them as opposed to when I am alone in my own server. Nevertheless, always a fun time. Just takes a while to get the hang of; particularly the strengths and weaknesses of each selectable character; though once you find your preference, it feels nice to get cosy with their unique abilities. Personally I play Wendy, as the assistance of her ghost-pal Abigail helps me negate the issues I have with connection when attempting to combat foes. I love my little killing machine girlie :)

Steam hosts "Don't Starve Together" as an immersive survival experience that thrives on collaboration and strategy. Its integration with Steam offers seamless multiplayer matchmaking, allowing players to team up or compete in challenging environments. The game's hand-drawn art style and eerie soundtrack create a captivating atmosphere, drawing players into its unforgiving world. Steam Workshop support encourages community creativity, providing access to a plethora of mods and customizations. While occasional bugs and balancing issues may arise, "Don't Starve Together" on Steam remains a beloved choice for cooperative survival gameplay, offering endless opportunities for exploration and discovery with friends or strangers online.

"Don't Starve Together" is a multiplayer masterpiece that seamlessly blends survival challenges with a unique, hand-drawn aesthetic. With over 100 hours invested, this game has become a captivating adventure that keeps delivering.

The multiplayer dynamic adds a new layer to the survival experience, emphasizing teamwork and communication. The diverse characters with their unique abilities enhance the cooperative aspect, making each playthrough different and exciting.

Crafting is a satisfying journey of resource gathering and adaptation to changing seasons. The looming threat of darkness keeps the gameplay tense and exciting, striking a perfect balance between exploration and caution.

What's truly commendable is Klei Entertainment's inclusion of a free copy with every purchase. While this gift-sharing feature is a fantastic gesture, keep in mind the region restrictions. Both sender and receiver must be in the same country, adding a unique twist to the gift-giving process. 

"Don't Starve Together" is not just a game; it's an immersive experience. Whether you're facing otherworldly creatures, exploring mysterious landscapes, or simply surviving the night, every moment feels like a shared adventure.

If you're in search of a beautifully crafted multiplayer survival gem that evolves with regular updates and a vibrant modding community, "Don't Starve Together" is a must-play. Don't miss out on the chance to dive into this cooperative survival world that continues to surprise and delight with each passing hour.
i want kiss webber

Genuinely the most tedious and uninteresting survival game I've ever played. I've owned this game for a good number of years now and have come back to it roughly every 8 months after some friend asks to play it and every time I lose interest immediately. The grind is boring, the combat is awkward and it really just doesn't feel satisfying to progress. Most games which don't emphasise progression have some capacity for creative expression like decorative base building or something satisfying to look back on after, and it just feels like that's something which is completely absent in this game. It's not that there aren't notable progression milestones you cross throughout the game, it's just that getting there isn't an enjoyable process and the dopamine spike isn't worth the time. The game shines in it's aesthetic as well it's sanity mechanics, which are creative and undeniably unique to this game, but aren't enough to keep me interested. I just really can't recommend this game, even if you're looking to play with friends.

*This is my personal experience and it may vastly differs from yours.

Individually, the characteristics of being challenging and punishing while offering little guidance should and always be welcomed in any survival game, but not all three of them at this level of nuisance. The result of this mixture with awful execution is that unless you spent hours on tutorials, tips and guides on youtube or having a party member who knows exactly what to do and how to do it, you will have to start a new game over and over since the game is a ticking time bomb and if you fail to make enough progress at certain points, you and your current world is fucked. Of course I can not say for everyone but personally I prefer a survival experience that can accept and absorb my lack of knowledge about the game being a new player in exchange for short term penalties (which the majority of survival games are capable of) instead of forcing me to start over and over not even sure what I did wrong and how to improve from it. The way to "gid gud" in this game have little to do with player's mechanics but to solely watch hours and hours long tutorials which does not at all encourage me to continue playing.

This game is a very fun game with friends, the boss hp is entirely fine and makes sense but i have way too much experience rushing bosses. Some bosses are mechanically unfun examples of crabking being either a boss you cheese for free or you put a ton of effort into a 6 minute fight where if you mess up once your fight is done you instantly lost you loose tempo and its done. Playing solo is fine but it requires much more effort than playing with friends. the bosses are fun and have variety to fight. You have a ton of options of what you want to do like rushing bosses or going as late game as possible to where almost everything is automatic. You can also decorate but that's sort of hard to do without paying money or playing for years getting them passively. Overall 9/10 this is a very mood based game in my opinion ill randomly play for 2 weeks straight or not play for months at a time but when i do play its always fun. Just try not to take the game too seriously that's when games become tiring to play.

This game is a very fun survival game that can be difficult if you don't know what your doing. I recommend watching a guide to make sure that want the game and to know how to survive. Very Basic Survival Tips: There are the four seasons every year, and a year is 71 days (9 and a half real life hours). Your first is Autumn is typically a time for preparation where there aren't an seasonal threats. Winter starts on day 21 and lasts till day 36. You need items such as thermals stones or any clothing with high instigation such as the breezy vest. Spring lasts from day 36 all the way to day 56. Spring is the wettest season of the game and when it rains you have a wetness meter. The wetter you get the more sanity you lose. Finally its summer which is the most punishing season of all. If you don't have an ice flingomatic your base will catch on fire, and if your not quick enough to react you can lose everything. The last tip is to put your thermal stones in a fridge so you will not over heat as quickly as you would without it.

I cannot make a better review than Indi-ana Jone, so i will put his here for those who stumble upon my review first.

"I should preface this by saying I loved Don't Starve. The core concept of this game is genuinely great and to play that core concept with your friends is a great time. The reason I can't recommend it is because of how the developers have been adding to the game since DST launched.

My main issue is that everything that's been added to the game since launch adds nothing to that core experience that was so great in DS. Survival is the name of the game, but everything (and I mean everything) added post-launch has essentially been optional content which poses no threat to the player unless they willingly indulge in it. Once you have a proper setup going, there are no more threats to you. The game doesn't have anything new to try on you once you make it a whole year, and whereas in DS you could always reset the world by leaving it and going to a new one, the only thing left for you in DST is the optional content. The surviving part once you get set up is stupid easy and the optional content is of noticeably lower quality than what's found in the base game. Again, the base game is great, but the devs have essentially just been adding useless bloat instead of building onto what makes the game great in the first place.

To grind my gears a bit further, the devs originally did intend to work on how the game scaled with players over the course of one's world expectancy with an update called Through the Ages. However, this idea was scrapped with what we're getting now (Return of Them) because according to Joew (Developer), the team had a discussion on what audience they wanted to appeal to during this change in direction. Essentially, they decided to reject the base of dedicated souls who were the original game's audience to instead appeal to the casual player, since they figure there's more of them and that means more people to buy those juicy cosmetics which are all the rage these days.

Not only has the new content not really added to the core experience of the game, they've also been doing kit reworks for a lot of the characters over time as well. However, the best way I could describe these reworks is simply, "bloat". Instead of doing tweaks and centralizing on a character's identity like the clamors for these character updates originally wanted, but instead adding a bunch of other mechanics and small things so that their kits ulitmately feel loosely cobbled together like a bad character mod. Not only that, but they do lore animations each time for the characters they rework, and god do they look genuinely terrible. Seriously, go look at the Woodie animation and then go look bad at the original DS trailer, its night and day, the art's taken a step in becoming an ugly clone of its former self.

On top of all that, the fourm has essentially become a hugbox for the development which is only accepting of positive feedback, which in my opinion is extremely lame. There's a lot of people who care about this game, the original audience, that they don't want to listen because in their eyes they cast their die a long time ago. I understand trying to reach out and connect with that casual audience, but I don't think you had to burn the bridge with the old audience to do so. Maybe a half and half instead of a 0 and 100 scenario, you know?

Some more knowledgeable people reading this might think I'm being hypocritical, since the caves are essentially akin to that optional experience I'm complaining that the devs focus on today. To counterargue, the caves are much more integrated into the base experience than anything new that Klei's been adding since DST's launch. You can access them from the start once you have a pickaxe and darting into the caves in many ways during the regular survival season is a smart move and it still feels like you're working within the main survival loop of Don't Starve while interacting with cave content.

Compare that, however, to the lunar island that's been added to the game in Return of Them. It takes a long while to get there, most threats are negated while being present there, and all the content that's there is some weird stuff you can do to get some juiced up tools. There's nothing much of interest there at all. Also, you could compare caves to just the addition of water in general; most threats in the game are entirely unequipped to handle some of the stupid things you can do with boats. For example, a character Winona can create automatic catapults which fire at enemies. They can be placed on boats, which has become the most effective way to kill bosses since most of them can't cross water at all. Ocean content is also very sparse, and houses the Malbatross and the Crab King, two of the worst bosses in the entire game, along with some more optional content which has you slave away at menial tasks not at all related to surviving in return for petty rewards.

But yeah, ignoring all that, the core gameplay which was made years ago still holds up today. A lot of people don't know how development has transpired and frankly won't care for the sobstory I just typed up, and that's fine. I bet my ass you'll love the core of what's being offered here if you've never seen it before, since regardless of what they do that core experience they've built their additional content onto is godly. However, if you reach the point where you realize you've survived what the game's thrown at you and are looking for more of it, Klei doesn't care about you at that point and you're never going to get anything other than some poorly-developed mods to feed into your interests.

I love this game, but I can't recommend it. The devs don't deserve your money until they straighten their act honestly, but if you just want to mindlessly play around every so often and buy all the cosmetics you can you'll probably have a blast."

I love this game a lot, but the input delay is an awful flaw that you just can't justify. In any other PvE game, even when you play on servers, combat is smooth. But in this game, everything, and I mean everything is server sided. That means that it doesn't matter if an enemy is 30 meters away from you on your screen, if it hits you server sided, it hits you. I am not an expert in game development, but how does every single PvE game but this one manage to make it so that if an enemy doesn't hit you client sided, it doesn't hit you server sided (unless your ping is like 500+). Kiting patterns are the bread and butter of combat in DST but you genuinely have to rely on tanking if you play with friends on a server. Also, how does one manage to make it so that you have lag on your own server? Without installing a mod that fixes it you have literal input delay to your own server. Yes, you get used to it, but you shouldn't have to get used to it.

It doesn't matter how good your PC is. You can play on a Soylent opener and on a Nasa Super computer and still have the exact same problems and the exact same input delay.

I love the humor and personality of various characters.  Especially the cute ones like Walter and Wurt.  The combination of light and dark, humor and horror in this game is wonderful.  I love catching butterflies and planting flowers just as much as trying to pick-axe statues in the ruins without alerting the clockwork bishops.

This is a game of preparation.  Be fed before you explore.  Bring a torch and a snack.  Accumulate enough minor items to fight mini-bosses for medium items.   Then bigger bosses for the best items.  All the while, exploring the world and slowly turning your little corner of a hostile environment into a relative Garden of Eden.

This is a hard game.  Until the skill trees, there was no leveling up your character.  You'd pretty much end up the same flawed weakling as you started, just with better equipment and bundling wraps full of health and sanity food.  Even with the skill trees, that's true, just with a few good tricks up your sleeve.

I love running in circles until one hard mob aggros on another.  I think this is so much cooler than turning into a superhero and killing everything yourself.

The bosses are well balanced for 3-6 players (depending on the boss).  After around 1,500 hours I started soloing Bee Queen as various characters, but I still usually have to roll back several times in that fight.  Consider the Automatic Health Adjust plugin for single-player unless you want to practice the fight for so many hours that you could have become a violinist instead.  Some characters have an easier time than others.  I guess I'm a Walter main, so YMMV.  At 1,800 hours, I've never fought Fuelweaver or Crab King, but I have cooked every dish in the crock pot, grown every crop to giant, completed Pearl's labors, and caught every fish in the sea.  My play style is much more about survival than fighting.

I'd say this is "the next Nethack" but it's not turn-based.  Don't Starve Together is so different from the original Don't Starve, yet looks very similar.  Skill at one doesn't entirely translate to the other.  Once I found the wiki pages for Food, Crock Pot, and Farm Plant, and some handy plugins, I was very happy.  Strongly suggested plugins:

* Insight - makes the invisible visible
* Global Positions - share the map with your friends, or with yourself in Wilderness mode.
* ActionQueue RB2 (RWYS supported) - save your tendons
* Craft Pot - avoid wet goop and monster lasagna
* Minimap HUD - see the map while you play
* Combined Status - see your temperature
* Simple Health Bar DST - or any other health-bar mod.
* Pick-up filters - don't pick flowers automatically
* Skins extender  - auto-open your "gifts" so it doesn't interrupt your game.

I wonder why the game doesn't include these features.

I sometimes "rollback" my server when playing solo.  It's much easier to recover from the last good day than from the last bad mistake.  Actually, groups of friends rollback their servers sometimes, but I never really settled into a group.

If I were to redo this game, I'd probably make intact ecosystems give you sanity and other bonuses and have destruction cause you to lose it.  Then I'd make going insane more deadly.  I'm not sure what I'd do then to still make it fun, but I wish that there was less benefit to killing, destroying and burning and more benefit to growing and restoring.

In short, I needed an escape from the world for a year during my divorce and some health issues and this game provided it much more than any other game.  I spent about 20% of my "play time" updating the wiki instead of playing the game.

God, this game used to be too good to be true.
Now it's just a skeleton in a museum.

I miss the events and the old ways the Devs thought and updates rolled out and Zark (where are you?)...
Try it if you must, if you're new, but remember - it's not what it used to be.

My most recommended game; that said it's not for everyone.

Unlike most other games in this genre, it's not a resource grind--in fact, it requires you to spend your time efficiently and to think ahead to survive.  Survival actually always feels like a threat if you ever stop thinking.  In that sense, can be like a psychological war of attrition (which I love).

Also, I love the atmosphere and the characters: dark, yet whimsical; each demanding a change in your play style as you learn to work with their strengths and weaknesses.

Gets lots of developer love (somewhat to the exclusion of its single-player older brother), even including support for multiplayer using community-created mods and finding other players.

There are a couple of mods I need to use to make this playable (removing some sounds and visual effects & reverting the crafting menu system).

If you think you might like this, then check out Oxygen not Included, also by Klei (singleplayer).

I'm making this review to celebrate hitting a full year of combined playtime in Don't Starve Together (4,571.7 hrs) and Don't Starve (4,199.2 hrs). I've been playing Don't Starve Together since it's release in 2016, and it's been a joy to watch it continue to grow and evolve throughout the years. It is one of my favorite games of all time, and there are so many things you can do in it. You can fight vicious creatures for powerful items, create cozy farms, and enjoy simply surviving in the Constant. If you ever get bored, you can use the world customization settings, console commands, and mods to create unique challenges and experiences for yourself. Just last week I had the idea to create an "Escape from the Moon Quay Island" challenge for myself that was really fun and got me to reconsider the resources available on the island. I've only just recently beat what are considered the final bosses in the game last month, and had a blast doing so. 

The one major downside to this game is unfortunately the multiplayer aspect. I've had to stop playing on all of the public servers for my own mental health due to multiple distressing events that I've experienced over the years, and this past October was apparently my breaking point. Even just looking at the list of servers is stressful now... It sucks, as I do want to have fun with other players. If anyone knows of any safe servers, please let me know in the comments.

I would recommend Don't Starve Together for anyone that enjoys a bit of challenge and enjoys survival games. I'd also recommend to avoid relying on the wiki in the beginning, as it is immensely satisfying to figure things out on your own. I still fondly remember the first time I played Don't Starve, finding a red mushroom and thinking "It's dangerous to eat random mushrooms in real life, that probably applies here too." I was right! I felt so smart for avoiding them back then, haha.
Really enjoy playing this with my friends even though we never get far. The style is something I love very much and I love the different characters. Would recommend getting this!

This game has become a Live Service Game.
It stagnates after a certain point and each subsequent update only really keeps you on the hook long enough for the next update to drop.
A lot of their recent decisions aren't geared in a way to maximize fun.
Many of the exploits and bugs are used in the game to make up for where it falls short, and when such bugs are discovered, they're patched, not even addressing the problem which makes exploits or bugs enticing to use.

For example caves. In it's nature, it's a hard place to traverse, but because of it's sporadic layout compared to singleplayer, it becomes tedious to maneuver around them and it really just becomes a safe haven against the season of summer.

To even make caves tolerable, one must exploit them to eliminate general tedium.

Also the decisions made with individual characters, for example, the most powerful characters before their rounds of buffs already stood at the pinnacle at the game, however, klei decides to give them more tools to make them more powerful.

Think about this, a character who can make plants grow at will, summon lightning, and is the most capable character to craft items without huge commitment also receives additional abilities to make it rain, which a precedent was set in single player for all characters to do this, summon the full moon which eliminates darkness and summons a school of fish, which completely renders the fishing minigame obsolete.

I could go on with the flaws and might even write an edit, but this game is currently in a live service hell with a misguided direction. Never pay full price for this game and never buy skin sets the day they come out.

This publisher is also owned by Tencent, the most unethical game company on the entire planet.

I rarely publish negative reviews but I believe this game deserves it. It's all the way punishing in the wrong direction. Hard, but not in a challenging way, so no fun. 80% of the things you can touch in this game is only there to either kill or annoy the hell out of you. There's absolutely no counter-play (in that moment) for most of the things the game throws at you. You die on specific timeframes because of some scripted, out of the blue boss/mechanic which is nearly impossible to handle in that moment if you haven't been preparing for quite some time or have the right equipment ready. Normally, I'd be OK with this as far as the game makes it foreseeable. But usually they're not. It gets boring and annoying really quickly.

If you're a fan of survival games and love a good challenge, Don't Starve Together is worth checking out. However, it's not a game for everyone, as it has its fair share of frustrating moments. When I first bought the game years ago, I quit after playing for 2 hours, and only recently just picked it back up to give it another shot.

One of the biggest downsides of the game is the lack of tutorials, which can make it very daunting for newcomers. You're thrown into the game without any guidance, and it's up to you to figure out how to survive. Some events like the first Deerclops attack or random summer wildfires can destroy everything you've worked hard for, and without any prior knowledge on how to avoid, it can feel disheartening.

DST is heavily reliant on the wiki. Players need to alt+tab frequently to look up information about items or how to progress, which disrupts the immersion of the game. Once you get the hang of the game however, it becomes a bit more enjoyable. You start to understand the mechanics and develop strategies to survive.

DST has several quality-of-life mods that can greatly improve the experience. Combined status, Geometric placements, Insight (item info display), and extra equip slots are just some examples out of the many. Would not recommend without at least some mods.

Don't Starve Together is one of my favorite games in the survival genre it adds more content and continues to flourish on the foundation Don't Starve set, whilst not completely changing the formula that Don't Starve is. the game is fun with friends and encourages you to try to survive with your fellow people, but yet the game makes it clear that this is completely optional, that you can survive alone, the game play is also not simply undermined by having a friend either. because multiple survivors bring in new upsides and downsides that everyone has to accommodate for one of you might not be able to eat meat, or the opposite. all of these things must be watched for, making almost every game play experience different.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The game does a great job of building a world and appropriate atmosphere. 

The hardest thing for new players are the bosses that come with each season- I honestly would turn them all off if you intend to learn this game. I additionally recommend turning Autumn (The most chill season) to very long to give yourself good warning and ability to prepare for the seasons or side objectives you want - like gardening with a gardeneer hat to learn all plants by name for future runs. Or taming a beefalo by riding it and giving it only enough twigs to ride and tame - so you don't waste resources (look up a video)

If you're an experienced Don't Starve Solo player this is a great game that with expand upon that knowledge and keep you on your toes... Just don't think that you'll be getting coffee for extra speed any time soon.

Uncompromising at its finest.

Dont Starve, a really intriguing game with a gameplay that can appear at the beginning of the usual where the goal is to survive. Graphics could make the picky ones turn up their noses, but believe it or not in the long run, not tired and is very cool. The exploration within the game is infinite being the huge map leaving out the various caves and biomes within it. One of the main points of this game are the monsters, it is possible to meet any unimaginable creature from giants to mutant monsters. The gameplay presents a huge variety of possible crafts that can allow you to build huge and creative bases, in addition to this you will also find several protagonists with skills that will allow you to vary your experience, the fights are quite simple as soon as you get carried away, they are quite schematic, that is, they attack themselves and expect the enemy to do the same repeating it until it dies, so it might seem boring but the atmosphere and the monsters you meet will not disappoint you in expectations. Survival within the game is really tough in almost all biomes, especially during the winter and summer, not to mention when it rains.
To conclude, I really recommend this game to survival lovers.

i absolutely love this game! even though DST is fun by itself, it's even more fun with friends. most sessions i've had with my friends always ended with us getting into some crazy situation and dying in stupid ways, and it's way funnier than upsetting with having to restart your world.

you can put lots of hours into this game; it has tons of replayability and you'll definitely get your money worth for the infinite hours of playtime you can get from it. there's always something new to learn and discover as the in-game days and seasons pass, so it's unlikely that you'll get bored anytime soon.

different to the normal DS, DST has fun reskins and clothing items you can unlock, which just adds to the list of things for me to do in this game, which i like. you also get rewarded with these things by simply playing the game, or even just logging into the game daily.

the game gets updated regularly so if you thought you were done... well here's something new to do! after all this time klei still update the game and listen to community feedback. they're such an awesome team and i'd totally recommend checking out their other games as well.

This game will get its hooks in you. At almost 3,000 hours I'm still developing mastery. Core gameplay loops, opportunities for adventure and advancement, ambiance and tone, and emergent storytelling are all very strong in this game. Peril lies around every corner, but systems are forgiving enough to allow you to get onto the learning curve and deep enough to reward you once you get the hang of things. Amazing alone or with friends. Just about the perfect game, and still receiving regular updates after 10 years.

Don't Starve Together is one of my favorite games of all time. If you like a sandbox survival game with a little more challenge than stuff like minecraft, this is the game for you. It has your basic mechanics like health, hunger, enemies, but then theres a literal sanity stat which makes you hallucinate monsters that will fight you unless you manage it. You can do so much stuff in this game. Want to just chill and survive? You can do that. Want to explore interesting land, ocean, islands, caves, and more? You can do that. Want to bring a friend? It's called Dont Starve Together for a reason. Want to watch OrangE youtube videos about dst lore over and over while you wait for him to post a new video? You can do that. Want to pin bosses against each other? You can do that. Want a final boss? Theres literally 2 and more content after that. There is so much personality and passion in this game. I mean Klei makes an entire character short per update. Yes this game is still getting updates. It's awesome. Here is a pros and cons list so this looks like a professional review:

Pros:
1. Good Character Variety. You can choose whoever you want each with their own ups and downs (except wx-78 hes my main hands off).
2. Good Enemies And Bosses. The enemies in this game are unique and interesting with their own attack patterns and varieties.
3. Crossover with terraria. If terraria did a crossover with it you know the games good
4. The progression. There is a lot of progression in this game, but it doesn't force you at all. The future updates add things in a way that doesn't punish any players not keeping up with it, instead giving more progressed players more challenges and rewards
5. The mods. I have never seen a game with modding as easy as this. Forget Tmodloader for terraria, this is the way to do it. All you do is hit the get mods button, choose to subscribe to the ones you want (completely free btw), and then you can enable them before launching a server.
6. artstyle. its good, im not an artist but i like it.

cons:
1. very harsh for beginners. ok i get it if you say this game is tough for beginners, but when it says an "UNCOMPROMISING SURVIVAL game full of science and magic," you should know what your getting into
2. Soundtrack. It's pretty bare bones. I don't enjoy it very much, but the simplicity matches the games tone. You dont want spiderdance from undertale type music blasting while your picking flowers and berries
3. Walter telling stories on the campfire. dont trust the sanity meter going up youre real life sanity will plummet
4. The rollbacking feature. I get its to avoid griefing but its just too easy to die and then push a button to have no consequences. Yes there are reviving methods in game and even modes that allow instant revives but if theres a button to go back before the fire hound burns my base and kills glommer, im gonna abuse it :(.


In summary, there is a reason my profile picture is chester.
one more piece of advice: dont trust maxwell mains trust
,P]KJMONI

After 2000 hrs this game is constantly updating and changing and improving. Klei has done a fantastic job of updating everything to keep up with, not only their ongoing lore in cinematic shorts, but also the ever-growing community of players.
There are tons of mods to customize your experience- some even supported by klei themselves- and even in vanilla DST no two games will ever be the same. 
Whether you're playing with friends, random people, or yourself, DST still proves to be a challenge especially for new players. The community itself is so welcoming however, and- true to the title- together you can learn how to survive and uncover many of the games bosses and secrets. 

Even if you're a "cozy gamer" please give DST a try. There are plenty of options to give yourself an easier more relaxed experience. You'll find that the overall artistic charm of the game coupled with all the different playable characters makes it all worthwhile.

If you're into lore btw, definitely go binge watch their cinematic shorts on youtube!

Absolutely fantastic open world survival game. It's hard and unforgiving but very rewarding. You need to keep your stats of hunger, sanity and health up in this world called the Constant, a dynamic world which changes with seasons, where seemingly everything is out to get you. 
It's beautiful hand drawn art style gives it a lot of character. The game is loaded with tons upon tons of content including multiple playable characters with their own gimmicks, enemies, bosses and mechanics like farming, cooking that will no doubt serve you with a lot of fun. 
This is basically Don't Starve 2. This a co-op game, but you can play it solo and still have a lot of fun, in fact most of my hours are playing solo. It's a must play for sure.

It's got an extremely steep learning curve, but once you've learned how to play, it's a ton of fun! It never becomes easy, so I've been able to play for hundreds of hours without getting bored, and it still gets updated frequently enough that there's always still lots to explore. DST isn't the kind of game that's going to tell you what to do or how to stay alive, so you need to be prepared to get into a pretty difficult experience, however, the friendly community makes up for the harshness of the game itself. There's tons of tips and guides online, as well as a very active modding community that you can take advantage of if you need a bit of help!

[h1]Don't Starve Together: A Survival Symphony of Quirks and Challenges[/h1]

[quote=author]Embark on a whimsical journey of survival in Don't Starve Together, the multiplayer expansion of Klei Entertainment's acclaimed survival game. Immerse yourself in a hand-drawn world filled with peculiar creatures, dynamic seasons, and challenging landscapes. With its unique art style, ever-changing environments, and cooperative gameplay, Don't Starve Together is a captivating experience that will test your wits and camaraderie. Can you and your friends endure the whims of this unforgiving wilderness?[/quote]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Don't Starve Together invites players into a surreal and unforgiving wilderness where survival is not guaranteed. Developed by Klei Entertainment, this multiplayer expansion to the original Don't Starve challenges players to navigate a world filled with eccentric characters, mysterious biomes, and the constant struggle to stave off hunger and madness.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Whimsical Art Style[/h2]
Don't Starve Together captivates with its hand-drawn art style, bringing to life a world that is both whimsical and haunting. From the quirky character designs to the bizarre creatures that inhabit the landscape, every detail contributes to the game's unique and memorable visual identity. The aesthetic charm conceals the dangers that lurk in the shadows, creating a delightful yet eerie atmosphere.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Dynamic Seasons and Biomes[/h2]
The world of Don't Starve Together is in a constant state of flux, cycling through seasons that bring distinct challenges. From scorching summers to freezing winters, each season requires players to adapt their survival strategies. The biomes are equally diverse, featuring lush forests, desolate deserts, and haunted swamps. Exploring these dynamic environments is a key aspect of the game's allure.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Cooperative Survival[/h2]
Surviving alone in Don't Starve Together is a daunting task, and cooperation is essential. Team up with friends in multiplayer mode to share resources, divide tasks, and face the unique challenges of the wilderness together. The synergy between characters and the division of labor add a layer of strategy to survival, emphasizing the importance of teamwork.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Character Variety and Quirks[/h2]
Don't Starve Together features a diverse cast of characters, each with their own strengths, weaknesses, and peculiar quirks. From the scientifically-minded Wilson to the enigmatic Wickerbottom, choosing the right character is a strategic decision. The unique abilities and personalities of each character contribute to the game's replayability, encouraging players to experiment with different survivors.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Sanity and Madness[/h2]
Maintaining sanity is as crucial as staving off hunger in Don't Starve Together. The ever-present threat of madness introduces a psychological element to survival. Encounters with otherworldly beings and the challenges of the wilderness can tip the balance, and players must find ways to stay sane amidst the chaos. The delicate equilibrium between sanity and madness adds a layer of tension to the gameplay.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Crafting and Base Building[/h2]
Crafting is at the core of survival in Don't Starve Together. Collect resources, refine materials, and create essential tools and structures to establish a base. The game's intricate crafting system rewards resourcefulness and innovation, encouraging players to experiment with different combinations to enhance their chances of survival.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Seasonal Events and Challenges[/h2]
Don't Starve Together keeps the gameplay fresh with seasonal events and challenges. From hound attacks to celestial events, the ever-changing landscape introduces surprises that keep players on their toes. These events add variety to the gameplay and provide opportunities for unique rewards and experiences.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Modding Community and Customization[/h2]
Don't Starve Together boasts a vibrant modding community that expands the game's possibilities. From custom characters and biomes to gameplay tweaks, the modding scene offers a wealth of user-generated content. The ability to customize the game enhances replayability and ensures that the community remains actively engaged in the world of Don't Starve Together.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Don't Starve Together weaves a tapestry of survival, exploration, and whimsy. With its endearing art style, ever-changing environments, and emphasis on cooperative gameplay, the game stands as a testament to the creativity and challenge that can be found in the unpredictable wilderness. Face the quirks of the world, forge alliances, and discover if you and your friends have what it takes to endure in the captivating and perilous universe of Don't Starve Together.

[quote=author]In the peculiar realm of Don't Starve Together, survival is an art. Embrace the challenges, unravel the mysteries, and embark on a cooperative journey through a hand-drawn wilderness like no other.[/quote]

Don't Starve Together is an excellent cooperative survival game that is best enjoyed with friends. The game is challenging but rewarding, and the constant updates and new content keep it fresh.

PROS
• Fun and challenging gameplay
• Great cooperative experience
• Regular updates and new content
• Large and diverse world to explore
• Lots of different characters to choose from

CONS

• Can be repetitive after a while

OVERALL
Don't Starve Together is a great game for anyone looking for a challenging and rewarding cooperative experience. If you're looking for a fun and challenging game to play with friends, Don't Starve Together is a great option.

RECOMMENDATION

Don't Starve Together is, simply put, a marvellous game with in-depth features and a high skill ceiling. 
From basic mechanics of health, hunger and sanity to day-and-night cycles, such simple systems weave together an intricate, delicate balance between life and death for your characters. Despite the game's title, starving is, in fact, the very least of your worries. The torrent of hostile mobs being in the game was so alarming that it struck a deep hesitancy in myself when approaching any mob the first time, even the adorable Glommer which I shamefully admit. 
Combat in this game is also wonderful. While I initially thought that combat would either be simply tanking, with lots of health restoring items, or dodging with a push of a button, this 2D game only requires you to move out of the way. Yet, this allows for greater mastery as you would not only need to time your movements, but calculate the distance moved by your character to maximise the number of hits on your desired target.
I'm grateful to discovering this gem of a game towards the start of my school break and exciting to delve deeper into what more it has in store for me.

[b]Don't Starve Together brings an enthralling survival experience that feels like a masterclass in cooperative gaming, perfect for players seeking a unique blend of survival and exploration. As a tech-savvy gamer, diving into this game feels like embarking on a thrilling adventure that requires both wit and teamwork.

[i]Pros:
Challenging Survival: The game offers a challenging survival experience, requiring players to manage resources, craft items, and navigate through unpredictable environments.
Cooperative Gameplay: Its focus on cooperative play is a highlight, fostering teamwork and communication among players, enhancing the overall gaming experience.
Unique Art Style: The captivating hand-drawn art style creates a visually appealing and distinct world, adding to the game's charm.
Varied Content: The game continually introduces new content and updates, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting.

Cons:
Steep Learning Curve: For newcomers, the initial learning curve might be a bit steep, requiring time to grasp the mechanics and survival tactics.
Permadeath Mechanic: The permadeath feature might be off-putting for some players, as losing progress upon death can be challenging and frustrating.[/i]

In summary, Don't Starve Together is a captivating survival game that thrives on teamwork and exploration. Despite its initial learning curve and permadeath aspect, the game's challenging survival mechanics and engaging cooperative gameplay make it a worthwhile experience for players looking for an immersive survival adventure with friends.[/b]

When people look at survival games they rarely view them as rogue-likes, but I think a multiplayer, survival, rogue-like is the best summation of the game. It doesn't have the end goal of its preceding solo game, but their is much more to explore and finding better and more efficient ways to survive is fun. This being the multiplayer version doesn't discount the fact you can still go in solo if you want, but I do think friends on other characters drastically helps balance out your own weaknesses.

I also find that the mod support is very good and can make things easier, harder, or just give some simple quality of life changes. The downside being linking your account to their website is a bit of a hassle but its a one and done thing.

-={ 9 / 10 }=-
Don't Starve Together is an addictive blend of survival, exploration, and social mayhem. Its charming visuals, deep mechanics, and endless replayability make it a perfect storm of frustration and fun, best enjoyed with a group of friends willing to laugh (and maybe cry) together as you navigate the madness of this quirky wilderness. Just remember, teamwork makes the dream work (sometimes), and duct tape is your best friend when things get hairy (metaphorically, of course).

-={ GAMEPLAY }=-
Shared survival, double the fun: Work together (or maybe against each other) to gather resources, build fortresses, and explore the ever-changing world.
Diverse playable characters: Choose from quirky personalities with unique traits and playstyles, adding even more chaos and strategy to the mix.
Hilariously brutal world: From shadow monsters to exploding turkeys, the game revels in its dark humor and unforgiving nature.
Constant updates and expansions: New worlds, characters, and challenges keep the experience fresh and exciting for years to come.

Steep learning curve: Mastering survival mechanics and navigating the unforgiving world takes time and practice.
Random can be brutal: Unforeseen events and harsh winters can easily wipe out unprepared players.
Griefing can sting: Be wary of mischievous friends who might turn your co-op adventure into a chaotic prank fest.

-={ PRICE }=-

[h1]Don’t Starve Together: A Fun and Challenging Survival Game[/h1]

Don’t Starve Together is a fun and challenging survival game that you can play with your friends or strangers online. You can explore a vast and varied world full of strange creatures, dangers, and surprises. You can craft items and structures to suit your survival style, and cooperate or compete with other players. You can also unravel the mysteries of the Constant, a mysterious land ruled by a new shadow queen.

The game is constantly updated with new content and features, such as new biomes, mobs, recipes, and craftables. The game also has a vibrant and helpful community that creates mods, guides, and fan art. If you are looking for some good tutorials, I recommend these YouTube videos:

[list] 
[*] [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-pl8snAL0YE&ab_channel=Jazzy%27sGames]EASY Starter Guide for Beginners | Don’t Starve Together: [/url]This video will walk you through Day 1 of a new world and talk about how to survive in your first Autumn, how to fight basic mobs, what to gather, and how to tech up as you map out the world. 
[*] [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLiwC0czRopZEzIbLxlwP6FgjPbxVSogp5]Don’t Starve Together - Tutorials:  [/url]This playlist contains 18 videos that cover various topics such as tips, tricks, strategies, farming, fighting, and more. 
[/list]

Some tips for beginners are:

[list] 
[*] Don’t starve! Always keep an eye on your hunger meter and eat food that restores both hunger and health. Cooked food is better than raw food, and crockpot recipes are better than cooked food. You can find some crockpot recipes here. 
[*] Don’t go insane! Your sanity meter will drop if you are in the dark, near monsters, or near certain objects. To restore sanity, you can wear certain hats, eat certain foods, or pick flowers. You can also use a tent or a siesta lean-to to sleep and regain sanity, but they will cost hunger and time. 
[*] Don’t be afraid to die! Death is inevitable in this game, but it is not the end. You can respawn at a touch stone, a life giving amulet, or a meat effigy. You can also be revived by another player with a telltale heart. However, each time you die, you will lose some maximum health, which can be restored with a booster shot. 
[*] Don’t be alone! Playing with other players can make the game easier and more enjoyable. You can share resources, help each other, and learn from each other. You can also play different characters that have different abilities and perks, and complement each other’s strengths and weaknesses. 
[/list]

I hope you found this review helpful, and I hope you enjoy playing Don’t Starve Together as much as I do. It is a game that will challenge you, surprise you, and make you laugh. It is a game that will make you say: [b]“Don’t Starve Together? More like Don’t Stop Together!”[/b].

Don't Starve Together is a fantastic multiplayer survival game that provides hours of intense and challenging gameplay.

The game is set in a whimsical yet dark world, where the player must navigate through a procedurally generated map, collecting resources, crafting tools, and managing their hunger and health. One of the most exciting aspects of Don't Starve Together is the addition of multiplayer, allowing players to team up with their friends or strangers to survive together.

The graphics in Don't Starve Together are outstanding, with a unique art style that adds to the overall atmosphere of the game. The environment is beautifully crafted, and the creatures and characters are creatively designed. The attention to detail is impressive, and it's clear that the developers put a lot of thought into every aspect of the game.

The gameplay in Don't Starve Together is both challenging and addictive. From gathering resources to battling monsters, there is always something to do. As players progress through the game, they will encounter new challenges and unlock new items and characters, keeping things fresh and exciting.

One of the things that sets Don't Starve Together apart from other survival games is its emphasis on teamwork. Building and managing a base with other players leads to a sense of camaraderie and satisfaction when overcoming difficult obstacles together. The game also allows players to revive each other, adding an extra layer of teamwork and strategy.

The developers of Don't Starve Together have done an excellent job of keeping the game updated with new content and addressing any bugs or issues promptly. The community is also very active, with players sharing tips, tricks, and mods to enhance the game even further.

Overall, Don't Starve Together is a must-play for those who enjoy survival games or simply want to have an immersive multiplayer experience with friends. Its unique art style, challenging gameplay, and focus on teamwork make it a standout in the genre. I highly recommend giving this game a try.

It is an interesting and fun game, and as a fan of the original game, I was super hyped for the co-op release. But this version has a giant flaw of not having enough respawn capabilities, which at times just feels horrible. The fact of how 'expensive' respawning a teammate is, and how fragile your lives are by design, really is a very poor combination for an enjoyable co-op experience.

As it stands, the fact of how easily you could lose everything was, in a sense, a heart-throbbing game mechanic which is more exciting when playing by yourself. But when you are playing with somebody else, and either one of you ends up dying early on, it becomes a time-consuming chore to invest all of your time and resources to simply let your partner be able to play with you again.

A simpler, cheaper respawn item would make a huge difference. Perhaps a voodoo doll or a simple Minecraft-esc bed would help so much in making the co-op experience, basically the reason you would buy this version, worth the trouble.

I really don't know why you'd play this, nor why people still continue to.

You need to know what you're supposed to do via player-made guides before you even start, and, after that, you'll just... Do that. In an archaic engine. Forever. There's no endgame, or "game" even. It's really more of a simulator with skins.

Characters are... Well, they exist. Keeping the simulator thought in mind, they're just different people to experience this game as. That's it. They have different playstyles if you learn what those playstyles are beforehand, but even then, they're not concrete and can just be... Worthless traits. Like Wurt or Winowa. 

Then there's the skins and drops. Yep. In a simulation game. They're boring, but sellable on the steam market for pennies, so... I guess enjoy that if you want...?

In conclusion, this isn't a game. It's a bad survival simulator. Go play something like Raft or The Forest if you actually want a good survival game with objectives and meaning.

PS: It just broke suddenly one day and now I can't connect to any server in just this game only. Every server's ping is ???? or something normal to 2,000, but none are joinable, so, rip.

There's evil dogs, giant cycloptic deer, humanoid pigs, angry walrus people, monkey pirates, a giant goose, walking trees, killer vegetables, giant potatoes, evil ancient skeletons, darkness that kills you, robots, big spiders, evil frogs, your grandmother...

Oh, and you also have schizophrenia. Honestly it's a great game

Don't Starve Together is a brilliant adventure that immerses you in a mysterious and dark world of surreal survival. This game doesn't just ask you to survive, but provides a unique experience full of mysteries, dangers and exciting adventures.

One of the game's greatest assets is its unpredictability. Each new launch is an exciting journey into an unknown world filled with strange creatures, mysterious artifacts and desperately needed resources. You will constantly find your way through dark forests, explore caves and fight for survival in conditions that change according to the whims of chance.

The graphics and style of the game are amazing. The unique dark art design creates a unique atmosphere that gives the project a recognizable character. There's something new and surprising around every corner that keeps you interested even after hours of play.

However, Don't Starve Together's real strength comes in its multiplayer mode. The ability to survive with friends adds a whole new level of fun and challenge to the game. Teamwork and strategy become the key to success, with each player bringing their own unique skills and ideas to the table.

Despite the challenges it faces, Don't Starve Together creates a surprisingly rich and captivating world that forces you to believe in yourself and explore new horizons of survival. This game is a true masterpiece in the survival genre, capable of captivating and capturing your attention from the first minutes of the game and holding it for many hours.

I could never in good-conscience either recommend, or "not" recommend this game.

I always enjoyed it, and have over 1000 hours, and met lots of friends through it, so I could never say 'no'. Yet buying it for a number of friends from other places always had the same outcome - they'd ragequit and never come back. Given how long the cycles take in this game, there's no way anyone would be able to get their money back on steam once they learned they don't like it. So I could never say 'yes'.

It had quite a special place. Always utterly destroying the player for making mistakes they didn't know they were making. Truly feeling like you'd be exploring a new wilderness. And eventually, you'd conquer it. Every down side had an up side. Monsters that would attacked you dropped resources, that used properly could benefit you.

But recently the game's been morphing in to something... different.

It's not even really the same game.

It started with "farming", fishing, and boats which was fine. There was no real 'crippling down side' to it. But I guess they wanted to make it more noob-friendly in a way?

But then they started adding stuff from other games in what feels like a desperation to fit on or be recommended. 

Progress trackers, levelling, and annoying sound effects. Things that never belonged.

It Felt like a genre-creator. Now it just feels like an over-stimulating mess.

Given how old the game is by now, it's become an easy 'no'

> Start a coop game with a friend, established a decent base after few failed attempts.
> Survive almost end of winter and miraculously defended our base from monsters.
> We thrivin.
> Burn a tree to get some coal near to our base since it was the only tree remaining near our vicinity.
> It looks far enough it wouldn't reach our walls.
> Miscalculated, it burned a single wall and started a chain reaction.
> Mitigate it by destroying some walls and structures to stop it, turns out dropped items would also burn.
> Hours of resource gathering just burned to ashes in just a few seconds.
> We're now starving. It is what it is.

i dont see it. negative reviews saying "its good, but not for me" suck, because thats not criticism, and not a reason to "not recommend" something, so i'll try to elaborate with basically no spoilers.

TL;DR 
tedious. unclear/unintuitive progression. wiki perma-open. difficulty is a do-not-do list

for clarity: i didn't get far into the game, but i did try for 30 hrs (many runs, on many different days). im not typically bad at games, but i was slow in how i played this game, and runs died often. im also of the opinion that it shouldnt take 30 episodes for a show to become good. this also applies to video games. 30 hrs is plenty.

the game is difficult, but its not a difficulty that makes you feel like there's a challenge to overcome (at least not for the first 30 hrs!). you just die for some reason and have to restart. the difficulty honestly is trying not to do things that have any risk (which is where any fun is imo), so then the game difficulty becomes a list of things youre not allowed to do, which is fitting for the game title

i dont feel any reason to progress through the game. no clear objectives, no intriguing items/places/enemies, no in-game guides, i didnt see anything. there's some crafting involved, but i dont even know what to craft or how to craft or even what progression is unless my friend is holding my hand through it. is that the fault of the game? or is it my fault for not seeing/exploring/understanding enough? i dont even know. can you blame ignorance? 
i personally dont find it fun to have a wiki perma-open in another tab for me to find out what to do next. or to need a friend to tell me how to play CONSTANTLY. it's possible to find out what to do without the help, but it's not intuitive at all. i was just crafting random sh*t until random sh*t happened, unless, of course, i was told what to craft. again, is this my fault or the games fault i dont know. so again, can you blame ignorance?

genuinely the only time i was having fun was when i was just running around exploring, trying to find some challenge to overcome. but then it turns night, which is no-fun-allowed time. but there wasn't even that much to explore anyways. not that every game needs to have all kinds of shit to explore every which way you go, but any time i explored i found maybe 1 semi noteworthy thing- "holy crap, another statue!!!!" i was mostly just hitting rocks and picking up sticks and grass...
thinking back on it, i often turned getting-back-home-in-time into the most fun i'd have, which is often when i'd die.

the (common) enemies just feel like common obstacles, and the combat is basic, but you shouldn't even try to fight enemies (just another item on the do-not-do list), so whatever...

i guess im the outlier. i generally love these kinds of games (terraria and factorio are a couple all-time favs), but i dont understand why people like this one at all. art style is cute i guess...
but you do you bros

Adding skill trees to all the characters is the dumbest thing you could do to this game.  It's the most anti-Don't-Starve update I could possibly think of, especially seeing as the progress for the skill trees is shared between worlds for some reason... what the hell is that?

This isn't an MMO, and it used to be a survival game.  And the best part about it was that everything that you gained in a run was part of that run, like a classic roguelike -- and I use the term roguelike intentionally here, instead of roguelite.  The fact that I can grind out 300 hours on a character to fill out a skill tree so they're super powerful for the next time I jump into a game with someone is fucking terrible and ruins the core part of this game that used to be good.

Klei is out of ideas for interesting updates and is just trashing their original game for new content at this point.

I love this game a lot but I am going to say it rn, it is NOT for the weak. trying to survive and live through loads of conditions and fight monsters etc makes the game very exciting and entertaining and kinda differs from other survival type games which can be repetitive. dst changes things up in a way i love but can be frustrating at times because sometimes you just cant find the right things you need and once you die you lose all your stuff and have to start over unless you have certain things which just makes it a lot tougher. but the good thing about it being a higher difficulty level is it doesnt really get boring. it doesnt get old like other games and thats what i like. and the starting over aspect doesnt get old because you get different stuff and a different world everytime. theres also lots of settings you can tweak, you can host a game by yourself or with friends, or browse and find other games. overall i rate it highly and i enjoy it a lot, but it is rough and can be frustrating. i recommend it to people who like survival games and like a challenge when they play and not something easy and repetitive :)

Don't Starve Together is a game where You start out with no info with what the world has to offer. The first time playing the game has to be the most fun, due to not knowing what was happening. And not knowing what is happening is the fun part of Don't Starve Together. You might die on your first day, but you will learn things over time. You first might survive for 2 days, and then 3, and 4, 5, etc. What I'm trying to point out here about this game is that this game makes you think. Let's say you die on your first time playing. You will learn a game mechanic or not to do something. Then, you will improve and get better. Don't Starve Together itself could be hard for some people to understand, but is insanely fun once you pick it up. Good game design, many things to do.

Despite the game being over 8 years old it still gets several major content updates every year and they're all free. The only content behind a paywall are cosmetics or new survivors, neither of which are crucial to enjoy the game. If you still want those things without paying real money it is possible to grind for them, it's gonna take a while but it is possible to do.

There's lot of characters to choose between for varied playstyles and lots of cosmetics to customize your survivor. 

You can also customize almost everything in your world to suit your own playstyle wether you want a challenge or just want to explore and build a base.

The survivors quotes are fun and they each have unique personalities. The instrument choosen for their voice also adds to their personality. 

Did I mention you can also have pets? Who doesn't want to have a kitten, puppy, dragon or bug(?) following them around everywhere making noice if you forget to feed them.

I've been playing Don't Starve Together practically forever, I install it on every device and I really never get tired of it!
Beautiful  graphics, interesting and well-developed characters, sandbox survival really well done, it doesn't bore you!
A raw pearl that worked to perfection becomes truly a jewel to be treasured in your library!
