Danger! A very positive review!
  The first thing that caught my eye was the unusual drawing style and design of everything in the game. I found it very attractive!
Also I really like the games like Terraria and Cult of the Lamb and others like this genre, and those collaborations just blew my mind. I like to see different games collaborating together. Just look at the Lamb drawn in the Klei style or the Deerclops drawn in the Re-Logic style - They are simply magnificent!
  Design of the characters is very memorable, and I can say who is who, what is what and ignoring the color stuff (Yes I am actually colorblind and this variety is called Protanopia.). In the game I didn't feel any discomfort as a colorblind person, and I CONSTANTly enjoy it like a child in every game (If theres no discomfort ye.). Personally, I have a hyperfixation on Wilson, Maxwell and Woodie (Ah yes more like 90% of those 96.5 hours of gaming it all was Wilson, but I saw the gameplay of other characters and all I can say - Magnificent. Also I like those robot, imp and that plant-dude!)
  I was playing the game on the old stages of its life on my friend's laptop and thanks to this game I have a good memories and kind of childhood maybe. And still. And I love to see where this progress this game is making (I feel like I am an uncle watching my brother's son grow up.).
Now briefly for those who wanted to see accurate facts and not just stories from my life;
  Minuses:
- Just one. I remember that I missed mine Insight point and it dissapeared to nowhere (I just opened the Insight menu and didn't choose anything.) by playing as common Wilson. It made me sad but I will recover those points by playing further heh. This says that game has some bugs, but hey, every game has its own bugs. (Also I heard about Shadow Obelisk bug.)
  Pluses:
+ At first this game has A LOTS of content. It may be a minus if you are a lazy-player. I reqired like 50 hrs of game to get to stage with crops and my first bosses (They were Bearger and Deerclops, but I feel sad for Bearger, he is too cute and I wish I could tame him or calm him down so he goes away.) and now I am on my way to learn how to defeat that boss in magma pools biome. ALSO I recommend to learn this game by yourself without wiki! Yes you can pass thru a lot of stuff, but it worth it.
+ At second I am very happy that I can play this game with mine friends. We can explore the Constant and its monsters and starve TOGETHER. We had a lot of funny moments and I am sure this won't end. 
+ At third this game is playable if you have no wish or possibility to donate, and you know the current situation with games without me for sure.

AND at the end I will say if you are too lazy to read all this stuff, here is a four-word summary: I love this game!
And if someone of you has any advises for my current stage of game I would be very happy to see!

Klei Entertainment, thank you for all this! This is one Game of the year for me :D Happy New 2024 year!

Playing Don't Starve Together has been quite the adventure i've spent countless hours trying to keep my character alive, only to be devoured by a pack of angry spiders or accidentally set myself on fire while trying to cook dinner. BUT hey, at least i've mastered the art of starving together with my friends!!! Who knew that surviving in a virtual wilderness could be so on hilariously challenging? This game has definitely taught me the importance of teamwork, communication, and not underestimating the power of a cute little rabbit So if you're looking for a game that will test your survival skills and provide endless laughs. Don't Starve Together is the perfect choice !! Justt remember to pack some sanity-boosting items because you will definitely need them !  ( i know no one will see my review but thank you for reading and watching it and have a nice day :D )

Probably my favorite game aside from a few others, its really fun to screw around with your friends, mess around with mods, actually try to make progress, fight bosses, farm random things you'll never actually need, and a ton more. My best world is roughly on day 5200. The characters are great and the lore runs deeper then the pothole in front of my driveway.
The only problem I've ever had was this "dedicated server failed to start." error which made me mad for a few days until I got it fixed. Overall, 9.8/10 game would recommend, whether your a loner and have no friends, or have a bunch of friends.

What I enjoy the most about Don’t Starve Together is how new content is regularly being added by the devs and how It’s got an amazing community that’s constantly pumping amazing workshop mods like crazy.

Although the game has lots of content and an amazing art style, it can be really hard to get into for it doesn't really do a great job at teaching you how things work... and perhaps that was intended by the devs. Regardless, unless you're constantly looking at the wiki, using overpowered mods or you’re playing with someone who has a decent amount of experience with the game, you are guaranteed to die a lot. It can be really frustrating, specially if you’re playing solo. But if you are willing overcome the frustration, it might become one of your favorite games.

I absolutely love this game and am practically addicted to it. I have never had a bad encounter with anyone while hosting servers. Instead, I have met and made many meaningful connections/friendships with the sweetest of people who have joined to play with me. I cannot recommend this game enough to anyone, especially those who enjoy Minecraft, Stardew Valley, and other survival/crafting games of that sort. It is visually stunning and very endearing to those who have an infinity for darker games or those who adore the Tim Burton style! The gameplay is very enthralling and you will find yourself having trouble putting this game down even for a moment. It seems that I am always finding/discovering new interesting aspects to Don't Starve Together and that keeps me coming back to play time after time. I have been a fan of this game ever since it was released and you can tell the love and effort that the creators STILL put into this game.

Don't Starve Together is my favorite game of all time and an experience unlike any other. It is a true masterpiece in the survival genre and completely innovates on it and constantly innovates on itself with a very frequent update schedule. There are 18 unique characters including DLC and almost all of them change your play-style in meaningful ways. The amount of content in this game is staggering, now boasting 20 unique bosses and with an unreal amount of enemy variety that are high quality and unique in their A.I. If survival games disinterest you with the level of grinding required to get results, I completely feel that. DST provides character specific and also a huge variety of ways to get very common resources needed for a slew of different crafting recipes, so any grinding is mitigated almost completely by game knowledge. If you're into base-building, this game is very in-depth with its structures and turfs that can completely change how an area looks while making use of the games bird-eye's view perspective. There is really something for everyone in this truly special game.

You could keep reading me suck this game off, or you could just go and buy it. It's only 14.99, and it goes on sale very often. Have a good rest of your day.

I like this game because it's f2p friendly, gets regular updates, and the community is rather chill. 
[b]F2p friendly[/b]
- You can obtain DLC characters and skins(purely cosmetics) via in game currency(spools) or monetary transactions. It is not hard to amass spools, as the devs gives out Klei points every update which can be converted to into a decent amount of spools.

[b]Regular updates[/b]
- Not counting bug fixes you get a an update every few months.

[b] Chill community[/b]
-From my experience in Public Klei servers, you'll meet people are generally friendly plus some occasional griefers.

Wasn't very convinced about this game when I first saw it. But 500+ hrs in - and at the time of writing - the game with most hours invested in it - I highly recommend this game. The art style is something you either love or hate - but I found it really suiting to the atmosphere the game conveys.

Lots of stuff to explore (with new stuff introduced every now and then), different challenges every season, tons of community mods - highly recommended. I am about 600 hours in, and I still feel like I'm scratching the surface.

My only issue with the game is lack of any form of overarching campaign - unlike the original Don't Starve, but multiplayer makes up for that! One has also got to appreciate that the devs are still maintaining and updating the game to this day!
Great Game

Admittedly I'm making this review because of the Autumn Sale event. With that out of the way, I completely recommend this game.

You will likely die, a lot... I certainly did in the beginning. And over time, got good enough to manage basic survival on my own. This game is harsh, and quite unforgiving. I don't think I have any issues with the game itself. In fact, I'm glad the devs continue to still work on it. I don't think there's an update yet I dislike. And the shorts they create along side them are wonderful. I haven't tried all of the characters after their update, but I am glad that they did character refreshes. Wolfgang and Wx needed one the most. Since one would eat up all the food, and the other would eat up all the gears. But those issues are no more. The only refresh that seems to have an issue, is Wormwood's ability to make regular berry bushes. They require juicy berries to craft, which spawn on a different berry bush. And unless I've missed something, which is possible, they don't spawn in the same world. So you either have one or the other on the map, never both.

As you can see from my playtime, I clearly like the game a lot. But this game also takes a lot of time to "progress." I don't really consider that to be a con. But it becomes frustrating when dealing with certain players. It's one thing to be new, or a noob. We've all been there. But there are some with nothing to do in their lives besides troll. I happened to still be alive on an official server by myself. When someone joined trying to convince me to restart the world. When I didn't give in, they tried to jynx me hoping I would die during the hound wave. I didn't, so they, somehow, found where I was and used a fire staff to burn down my base. And because it was just the two of us, there was nothing I could do about it. What made it worse, is there were several US servers that were probably already empty that they could have restarted.

Now obviously this sort of thing isn't new for online games. And if the server had more people on it, that person would have been kicked. And the server would have been rerolled to the previous day to repair the damage. But it is something that still has the potential to happen, so it's worth mentioning. Especially when so much real world time spent progressing through a season can get ruined by just one person at a moments notice.

I guess another con could be that it's sometimes hard to understand what to do besides survive. It's hard for me to adequately speak on this topic, because I've played the game long enough that it's hard to put myself in the shoes of a new player. But the devs felt similarly and made changes to the ui that they hoped would help address those issues.

All in all, it's definitely worth trying. I feel the game has something for just about every type of player. Base building, cooking, gardening, fighting, exploring. And even has mod support, some of which are usable on official servers. Generally, the more people you have, the better your chances at survival.

Edit: It is possible to have both berry bushes on the same map. I'm not sure how often it happens, but sometimes the other type will be in the caves. So as long as you have caves enabled, there's a chance for the other berry type.

This is the best game I've ever played , but you don't have such fun without a friend. This game is really hard if you don't use some mods and you won't be able to do a lot of things if you don't watch some guides .
Edit: I love how much new content gets added into this game. Anyway, I got a lot better at the game and I realized the skill gap this game has to offer. Time is more important than anything in this game. When you first start, the hard part is just staying alive and making yourself all the items for the next season. But, when you get better, you only want speed, you want to make progress faster. For me, I usually kill dragonfly and queen bee in the first autumn, as well as do a ruins rush and go on the sea. All these are impossible when you first start playing, but with experience you can go as far as killing most bosses in the first autumn. Thanks for reading.

8 years and going on DST. It is definitely among the best on my list. Though I would only recommend it if you've got friends to play it with as it could get a bit tedious playing alone (hence why despite my love for DS Shipwrecked, I don't play it that much - this is also my plea to Klei to release DST Shipwrecked (pls)). 

Super fun, with tonnes of customisations and game modes. It still has a steady stream of updates and new content, despite being out for almost 10 years, which keeps every exciting and fresh. Art style is unique and gorgeous. Creative gameplay. I quite like the fact that there is no tasks other than the main objective, which is to survive, as it gives me the freedom to play the game and explore however I want and even more so with the copious content from the modding communities. 

Overall, 1000000/10. Absolute classic. Would highly recommend!

Don't Stave Together is an expanded version of Don't Starve, largely centered around playing with friends. It places players in an interactive and complex environment, in which the players struggle for survival. The content within is large and expanse-full however, it is difficult to beat on your own. You're going to die. But there's so many complexities to this game and I really appreciate the constant updates and community work Klei does for this series. Adding mods are easy and several are near essential for anyone who cares about organizing their base well. If you like base building survival, this is a great game for you. Playing solo is completely viable and you can kill all the bosses without help.

Oh and if you bought the game recently, check your steam messages for a second copy to gift a friend.

===

The DLC is entirely cosmetic aside from the DLC characters. However it is possible to unlock all the characters and skins (not including discontinued or specific purchase skins) without paying a cent, though it will take a long time to do so.

===

The game is constantly being updated, so the game is still very relevant despite being an old game. All in all, the game is well worth its price.

This game saved my life.

I am 50.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

What a good game this is and what a noob am I.

Holy cow this game is absolutely fun. It's literally just a game of survival and almost [i]everything[/i] can kill you, but it's fun. The style is my favorite thing about this game though. I bought this game just because I saw some old youtube video of it back when the game first came out, and wow. Just wow. It runs smoothly on all my computers and my mobile devices, and honestly the don't starve franchise is my favorite for just the lore alone - it's not obvious when you first play it or when you're new to the games, but there's a lot to think about in the storyline of these games that it really draws you in!

This game is especially fun with friends, but you can play alone as well! You can edit what you want your world to be full of resource-wise, you can add fanmade workshop items for more fun experiences, and you can just basically go ham on doing the things you want to do with no pressure. With friends, surviving would be a bit easier but just know those chaotic ones do have the power to set things on fire, even if they also worked hard to make said things.

The only gripe I've ever had with this game in all my time owning and playing it is that some of the events, like the arena battle ones, often drag out the worst in players and, if I'm going to be honest here, I'm just not one of those people who are hardcore into arena battles to the point cursing out your team is allowed. I do enjoy the arena battle events with my personal IRL friends, though, all things considered, so that's a plus for anyone who can drag up to six friends into this game during those!

Anyway, this game is really fun to me in that I can build any kind of base set up I want to, which really adds to the fun for me. I like to create bases and defenses, and this ability really made me glad, and I've thrown so much time into this game just building huge bases. It's really addicting, trying to see just how big you can make your little home!

All in all I love this game to bits and highly recommend it for both co-op players and single players. Even just people who like to just chill can enjoy this game. The workshop also makes this game amazing for solo players.

Sumary:  Crafting Neat.  Character Abilities: Neat.  Event handling: Terrible.  It's quite simple, if you do not have play control, you have nothing.  Might as well be watching a movie, really.  It isn't bad but targeting when dealing with a mob is very questionable as you often target the incorrect enemies.

Upon clicking on certain items and even creatures, it will state the intended action, but that action often is not carried out.  This means if you wish to run and attack a creature, it will merely have you run up to the mob and the even that is to be carried out never happens.  When picking up items, this will result in one staring at the item, often stooped over.  This is my primary complaint; it affects any sort of strategy I use in playing the game.

That being said, the game itself is wonderful to play as it is a great survival game noting the crafting, the generated worlds, the unique creatures, the challenge of surviving in a seasonal changing landscape.  Once several processes are understood, one can stay alive as long as he or she wishes.  There are benefits for people playing varied characters as each brings something to the table that can make the game easier in specific situations.

I feel this game is definitely worth the money, it's just a shame that it is receiving more features and more bugs get introduced.  On the other hand, it has definitely paid for itself based on the amount of content that has released since the game was purchased.  It's definitely a recommend to buy.

This is a truly great game at what it does and I strongly recommend it with a few caveats that will be included. There are two experiences the game provides and it is solidly backed up by the mechanics. The game can also be played on a potato without hurting its function, art style or atmosphere so that is a plus for coop with friends who may not have a gaming rig.

Firstly, it is a great survival experience. It puts you in an unfamiliar environment which you must learn and adapt to in order to survive and thrive. It is not, however, a survival simulation. You need to learn the many strange new rules of the Constant and will be surprised (and often killed) by unexpected phenomena and events. In many ways, this is a better simulation of real survival than an actual sim because it puts the player into the mindset of survival rather than merely the mechanics of it. This entire experience may be permanently skipped by reading the wiki, however.

The second thing that it gives is an experience akin to the Fey realms of Celtic mythology. The rules are arbitrary. Things change depending on season. There is little to no magic initially. By discovering the worlds rules and secrets, however, you can build power over the world and come to master it. This is something I have not seen adequately expressed in any other game before and have found to be a satisfying experience.

Now for some of the cons. As noted above, this is not a survival sim. It is a survival sandbox. If you come looking for something on the realistic survival sim spectrum you are going to be disappointed. 

My other major caveat relates to balance. Overall, the game balance works but there are a few points where I feel it is off. For one thing, there is a static balance and the game typically supports anywhere from one through six players. I feel that the balance is geared toward three or four players with one or two being too hard and five or six being too easy (if coordinated). They changed hit points from the original singleplayer for many entities and this does not really add gameplay. Instead it makes the fights tedious for single players and they are still too easy with three or four fighters (usually in party of three or four you will have one or two good fighters). Not a deal breaker and you can absolutely solo the entire game, but it does feel off. 

The other balance is the push toward combat. Despite framing itself as a survival game, fighting is the most important skill in the game. The best stuff is obtained by killing bosses and the non-combat solution to problems are always slower. This is a compounding problem because a combat character can simply face their problems head on and gain from the encounter. The less combat oriented characters take more time and get nothing in exchange. Over time this adds up and there is no payoff for the non-combat characters. Once again, not a deal breaker and I still love the game but it does limit some of the potential and pushes character choice in favor of combat characters (unless there is a really good benefit with the non combat optimized characters). If optimal play puts such a high value on combat that the benefit to a non-combat character needs to be borderline OP to make them a common pick then probably combat skill is too important in the overall gameplay.

DST is still a whole lot of fun and I highly recommend it.

I can say that it is one of the best games of its kind. Although it took me about 100 hours to solve the game, I have solved everything well now. The diversity and survival walkthrough system are actually pretty good.
The graphic style may not appeal to everyone, but I personally liked it a lot.

There is only one big problem with the game, and let me state it at the beginning;
- The game does not teach you how to play the game; It leaves you straight to the world. This is actually a good thing if the game is not complicated, but the game is not a simple game. I spent most of my hours searching for links between items on wiki pages. I watched the walkthrough online, there are a lot of fine details. And even though this is a survival game, you can't proceed with straight logic because the universe is a different universe and the crafts are different.

Dear Klei my only complaint is, since you are making an unknown game in a different universe, you should at least add something like a tutorial mode. To be able to solve the game. This is one of the reason why new players cant get warm up to this game.

But if we come to the main plus sides;
+ Really fun with friends. Even the single player mode is enjoyable.
+ I think it is very important to be able to mod the game and there is a mod workshop integrated into the game, which is quite nice.
+ Unique Graphics that would appeal to the majority. 
+ Boss variety, craft-food-item variety is very diverse.
+ The game never allows you to develop passively, so even if you are on the 300th day, you have regular daily chores
+ the past stories of the characters are quite sweet. Klei has made short animations for these characters on youtube. I definitely recommend you to watch it. In particular, the stories of characters such as wendy and willow has been integrated very successfully into the game.
+ As you play the game, the mechanics of easily obtaining in-game item drops and collecting them for better items by dismantling them are good, so they did not monetize the game.
+ the universe in which the game takes place is very beautiful. Although it looks isometric, I really liked the 3D cartoonistic feel.
Definitely buy and try with your friends.

Defiantly recommend Don't Starve Together to anyone who wants to spend hundred of hours overcoming challenges in a quirky but intimidating world. This game brings the challenges to the player (seasons, sanity, hunger, health, dangerous animals, weather, bosses, and much much more). This is a game that makes the player discover everything on their own, which may seem a little daunting at first. Without external help you may be lost sometimes, but as you play with others it's always enjoyable to learn as you go. 

In this game you can take on many roles to aid in you and your friends survival. You can learn to farm, learn to harvest resources, learn to fight. You can explore all of the biomes, the caves, the ruins, the islands, the ocean. There is so much to explore! In addition to all of this, there are several bosses that are challenging but rewarding to defeat. For most players, the game isn't about not starving but having fun doing so!

Don't Starve Together also includes 18 playable characters (4 are unraveled with in-game currency that is given to you for just playing) each of which have dramatically different play styles. You can be a master chef, a handy-woman, a bodybuilder, a plant, an average guy, a lumber jack, a librarian, a robot, a singer/actor, a mime, a monster, a boy scout, a literal fish, and many more. Each character has advantages and disadvantages that keeps the game interesting. Also they all have amazing skins!

After a while of playing this game you'll look back on your early days and all of the little challenges that seemed so big at that time will now be the least of your worries. Now you can experience the game for what it's worth, which isn't only surviving but thriving! Amazing game!

I first tried Don't Starve Together during a memorial day free to play weekend promotion. I immediately fell in love with the game for so many reasons. The sketchy art style gives the game a cartoon-y yet still eerie feel to it, bringing so much character to the world and characters within. Despite it's friendly appearance, this game is nothing but, and ironically starving is not the way you'll often find yourself dying. The combat mechanics while simple can be difficult for some to pick up, and the sanity management early game is a struggle at times. However, this game doesn't kick down at newer inexperienced players for not "getting good" and provides many solutions in it's large character roster that provide different experiences for everyone's play style. This game updates frequently, for free, the only additional in-game purchases are for purely cosmetic items and special characters that do not affect the experience of the game or lock out content. If you have a group of friends wanting to try a survival game that can be tricky to master, this one is worth a shot.
LABOUR OF LOVE !!!

If you're into stat management, inventory management, and crafting games, then you'll definitely enjoy this game.

You will need to not only manage your health and hunger, but also lighting, sanity, and your very tools in order to survive.

Get too hungry? Starve to death. Go insane? Shadows manifest abhorrent creatures to consume your being. Don't have light when night falls? The Matriarch of the darkness will strike when you least expect. 

Couple with events, DLC, cosmetics, and a steady influx of new characters with unique abilities, strengths, and weaknesses, you can certainly tell Klei is taking care of this game.

Especially after all this time. With numerous character reworks to take these single-player oriented characters to work better with each other in a multi-player setting, new characters to bring in new play styles (and even multiple singleplayer DLC exclusive characters slowly working their way in with each rework), and all with no additional charge to the base game?

Developers of this game are really passionate guys, I can tell. Does the sales often and also includes a gift for your friend. These guys are the real gamers who are constantly working to make this work and I can see that. Hopefully this game farther develop. If you like original 'Don't Starve', you are likely to fall for this one as well. Here's pros and cons of this game:
Pros: Get to play Don't Starve in multiplayer. Also RoG contents are included/in process (still beta after all)
Cons: Host-guest game sync issues (latency). Some bugs since still in development. Major bug is where server is no longer joinable by others or particular players. Many times not good game experience with strangers. Too many noobs. :p

Updated: Jan 2, 2016
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Klei is still making more contents! This really amazes me. Playing this game since the beta, I thought after official release from beta, no more contents would be made after fixing bugs. But game continues to add contents. Contents with background stories that puzzles players. The lores and the mysteries that it entails. Its amazing. Very in depth of a game. It takes a form of what is a survival roguelike RPG into deeper and deeper stage buildling on top of it. Who knows it might turn out to be something like of MMORPG? It has limitless potential. Only truely skilled players may be able to conquer the game to its depths.

Updated: Aug 17, 2017
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The updates are still coming, slowly. Devs have made skins as part of their revenue to be able to continue the updates, and the skins feel to have more quality than the update itself. New character release and character rework are being done, as well as progressive update on new contents (of which I believe is better to play when fully completed). Over recent years, I believe some updates need to be better thought through however. 'Return of Them' doesn't seem to hold close relation to the rest of the game set at this moment, feels distant and not uniquely desirable to do. Character rework for Woodie and Wendy are quite disappointing. The difficulty of using Woodie has always been the case, but the rework doesn't seem to make difference to that, nor useful other than the goose transformation and always existed fast woodcutting. The full moon transformation feels more like time waster than a challenge for experienced players. For new players, it'll feel like no other than instant death call. Worrying about food to eat for after transformation is more of a concern than actually using the content of transformation. Wendy rework for Abigail is something, but doesn't seem to be any more useful than before. Killing spiders has always been the same thing and that's about it. Trying to look and helping small ghosts is time waster that doesn't add time-worthy effect for Abigail. Willow rework seemed pretty good, except BERNIE! makes sound not matching for the game theme. Wortox on the other hand, I very much applaud on. Many characters still need to be reevaluated to be usable not only the beginning of the game, but also late game. Despite these cons, I feel like there are other  contents and characters that are very much worthy playing for, so still would recommend to play.

Don't Starve Together is a viciously unforgiving survival game and I absolutely love it. The art style stands out compared to other survival games the entire horror-esque  aesthetic is so unique to this game. The character's dialog and overall character design is charming, the lore is surprisingly deep and well thought out, the environment you're in can keep you on edge and this is overall a great game. Playing this game as a beginner is difficult and you  will die a lot, the best way to play when you're beginning is to play with friends or watch helpful beginner guides. There are many funny or traumatising moments that can emerge from this game and I highly recommend it. This game goes on sale often so be sure to check it out then.

I've spent countless hours playing this with Friends. The visuals are awesome, really blend with the sense of oddity that the game holds. Each character has unique Stats and abilities that can affect how each world you create is played. The multiplayer can be customized to be Cooperative, neutral, or full on war between players and everything else that's trying to kill you. The game is constantly receiving new content and skins that ensures it stays interesting.
With the newest content update It feels like the over world and caves have been completely refreshed. Quick Italian Tomato Pasta

Ingredients:
8 oz (225g) pasta
2 tbsp olive oil
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 can (14 oz/400g) crushed tomatoes
1 tsp dried oregano
1 tsp dried basil
Salt and pepper to taste
Fresh basil leaves
Grated Parmesan cheese

Instructions:
Cook pasta until al dente; reserve 1/2 cup cooking water.
Sauté minced garlic in olive oil.
Add crushed tomatoes, oregano, basil, salt, and pepper. Simmer for 10-15 mins.
Toss drained pasta in the sauce, adding reserved cooking water if needed.
Serve hot, garnished with fresh basil and Parmesan. Enjoy!

Loved the original Don't Starve and was very bitter for a long time that they reneged on their "no multiplayer" vow, citing it did not fit the concept of the game. Finally got tired of my favorite game franchise having no new content since the single player DS is finished and decided to pick up DST as I've long heard it's playable solo.

Well it's been, I don't know, not even 6 months and I already have more hours in DST than DS. Suffice to say it's absolutely worth your time, just know the survival aspects, particularly acquiring food, are somewhat easier while the mobs and bosses have more health. New bosses are substantially more difficult/complex than DS bosses and raid bosses require lots of time and resource investment as a solo player. You will probably require research and practice to learn the new bosses and how to defeat them. If you're struggling just know panflutes, weatherpains, gunpowder, and catapults are there to even the odds when fights are designed for multiple people. But it is absolutely do-able.

The characters are better after their overhauls and getting even more improvement now with skill trees. There is significantly more content in the game than the previous one. A lot of it, however, is starting to feel redundant, it's become a bit bloated. But, we have real late game content now. The steps to get to late game are...convoluted, and you'll likely need the wiki. Ultimately I'm constantly busy for about 3 in-game years doing stuff, with moderate base building effort, and progressing the game. It is even more addictive than DS. A mechanic to reward multiple runs with different characters would add to that. Alas, once you beat final bosses the skill tree branches are unlocked for everyone. 

DST still is receiving content updates btw. Possibly years worth. Highly recommend if you liked DS, just know this is a solid step up in involvement. If you don't like hidden mechanics you have to wiki(they have added a scrapbook mechanic to help this), durability on everything, and a general grinding aspect, you might not like this game. If you haven't played DS before, maybe go through DS+ROG before this. You really have to see if you find the game loop and art addictive. But yeah for 15 bucks I'm definitely going to amass over 1k hours so I think that speaks for itself.

The game is a bit hard, you will die a lot at first because there are a lot of dangers and you're still in an unfamiliar place. Once you understand how to take care of you primal needs, you're free to do whatever you want : from exploring the lands, to fighting monsters, makings animal friends/allies, farming and making sure you have enough ressources for the winter, creating your own place, sailing across the sea or exploring caves... Characters you pick also have very different gameplays. 

Even after 100h, you still discover new things when you play and it's still fun to try to understand how you should handle these situations. A huge plus is that Klei Entertainement still updates the game after 7 years. There's events based on real life calendar (Hallowed Nights, Winter's Feasts, The Forge, The Gorge, ...) , new weapons and characters, they rebuild old mecanics,....
Another great thing about Don't Starve Together is the community : there are tons of really cool mods ! You can play as who you want, some mods allows you to have very useful pets, others helps you with gameplay (shared map, respawn at camp, ....) it's fun to lurk in the workshop to see what exists.

If you want to play a game with your friend, this is a great game to pick ! Just be aware that some players might not like the fact that you could die on the spot from a meteor shower or an angry bird that you brought to camp by mistake :)

Don't Starve Together [u] was [/u] my favorite game. I remember playing the game with my cousins and friends all day during the pandemic, sometimes even up to four in the morning. 

I played it the most with my cousin, Krys. He and I were best friends, and we learned how to play the game together. We became so good at it too. We'd discuss strategies, send each other awesome mods we could add to our server, watch DST YouTubers and give each other tips on how to play certain characters. 

I remember he suddenly dropped by my house and stayed there for a week, and yes, all we did during that entire week was play DST like crazy. During Christmas I bought my friends and cousins skins of their favorite characters. For Krys, it was Wigfrid, because she was so easy to play and quite literally at times ignored the rules of the DST world. 

I'd forever treasure these memories.

Today was supposed to be his 23rd birthday. It's been months since I last even touched the game. Opening it is difficult, actually playing it is downright impossible. I look at our old servers together and realizing that I'll never get to play those with him ever again breaks my damn heart. 

Four hundred hours and still it wasn't enough time with him. 

This game is really great to play with friends or family. Learning how to survive in the DST world is fun in its own way too. The lore of the Don't Starve series is one of my favorite. I hope you guys can continue to enjoy this game in my place.

Happy birthday Krys, and I hope you're happy, wherever you are.

The entire game is just a massive wiki crawl with no real end goal. The mechanics are obtuse, and obscure,, and you regularly get fucked by monsters that come out of nowhere. And when you're not getting fucked, you wonder why you should do anything in particular past the bare minimum. At this point, it's hardly even a matter of having some kind of in-game guide, so much as the absolute need for one to even begin to enjoy this game.

The combat is clunky, and unfair, healing is difficult, crafting is a series of unintuitive menus, and the game's not really sure whether it wants to be a survival sim, or an exploration sim, or a combat sim, or whether it wants to have a story.

When you die, it can take hours to get back to your where you left off. Basically, there's no point in playing this game unless you have friends. And at that point, I feel like you're better off spending your money on a different multiplayer game.

One of my favorite games, can be difficult and frustrating without mods, especially for new players; but it's worth getting into and learning so you can enjoy it. I would recommend a respawn and possibly quick pick mod for new players.  There are many ways to play the game that can make it more or less difficult, and many different ways to succeed depending on preferred play styles.  They also update the game regularly with events and new characters/collectibles you can unlock. This is one game I always come back to, and when I get frustrated I just put it down for a bit and come back, worth the price and learning curve.

If you're on console, stick to the single player experience.

This game changed my life.
In any Co-op server I tended to base away from other people and live by myself like I was playing Don't Starve. Tending to my crops alone in the caves below, hidden from the surface dwellers. When I realized this I realized how messed up I was and decided to take a break to better myself in real life
Months later I returned to the game and I started doing the same exact shit but this time I'm only using Wolfgang. 
It truly is better to Don't Starve Together than Don't Starve.

There was once a young boy who would not hurt a fly,
Living on a small farm underneath the blue sky.
Now this story I warn you is not for those faint of heart,
For our sad tale begins with a boy's troubled start.
All the boy ever wanted was just be seen,
Noticed by his father who never meant to be mean.
He was absorbed in his work no time for play or talk,
And the boy grew to despise the click of that lock.
As the lonely days passed, jealous thoughts filled his mind,
The boy turned to naughtiness when once he was kind.
So he came up with a plan to get Papa's attention,
And one fateful night he broke into his father's collection.
Contraptions, treasures, and oddities galore,
He tipped over the glass case and it shattered on the floor.
Out came a spider, it gave the bad boy a fright,
Eight eye peeled into his soul and it lunged in for a-
Oh turn away my dear friend. I don't want you to see,
For this boy and this spider were not meant to meet.
For that night with one bite they became something new,
A boy and arach, now one no longer two.
His parents screamed and they yelled in fright at the sight,
And chased him away where he got lost in the night.
He was cold and was scared. he vowed he'd be nice,
He begged for a way to change back, no matter the price...

Don't Starve Together is more than a survival game. It's a statement on the life and world we live in, and our gloomy march to our inevitable death. I'm not going to sit here and tell you things you already know. [spoiler] "There's 4 seasons, stay away from darkness, for the love the cooked green mushrooms give sanity!" [/spoiler] You've heard that a million times. But what drives all these players to play? What makes somebody spend either less than 100 hours on Don't Starve Together or spend their entire life on it? I'd like to review that in this review.
[h2] This game is big [/h2]
Like, [b] REALLY [/b] big. Don't starve together has this 2.5D look to it, meaning that most things you see are just solid PNG's that rotate with the camera. It brings a sort of pop-up story book look to it. Stylish and compact. This also means that with all these simple pictures Don't Starve Together can handle a lot at once. Sure, multiple things have animations and movement and effects, but it's going to take a lot to crash the game [strike] except for that one time that one guy used pine cones. I digress. [/strike] And with such a large open space for creativity to flow, the devs let loose. Beautiful and amazing stories are told through the adventure your character takes from place to place, fighting battles and solving puzzles, all trying to stop the big bad guy [spoiler] Which one the bad guy is, is something still undecided [/spoiler] . It's a wonder how many people don't see how huge this game is. Letting a survival game get almost monthly updates for years means one thing and one thing only: those thousands of hours some players have were spent doing something, not nothing.
[h2] Re-Replayability [/h2]
You can only get so far in vanilla Minecraft. Live only in the caves, in the sky, no food, no weapons, no armor... you get the idea. But most of that stuff is for looks. Nothing really... changes. Don't Starve Together boasts a collection of 18 different unique characters, all fully updated and ready to go. You could play as one character and fight all the bosses, then go to the next, and the next, and the next. That's 18 different playthroughs if you the distance. And each character, with their unique mechanics, will have you going a different path each time (If you're looking for efficiency) Webber has his spiders, instead of his pigs. Wanda ages over time and does better when weak. Wigfrid is a carnivore, Wurt is a herbivore, Wormwood can't heal from food, Winona is temporary in your playthroughs, Walter doesn't exist, Wes... should be renamed 'hard mode' and Wilson is Wilson. So 18 different unique playthroughs. Well you could also take each character and try to kill a specific boss as fast as possible, or get down to this challenging area called The Ruins as fast as possible, or you could  try to make Twinkies as fast as possible. There's always a reason to come back.
[h2] This server has mods enabled [/h2]
Don't Starve Together has a passionate development team. And a passionate community. And when you give a community a game, what are they gonna want? A workshop. Don't Starve Together's style makes it pretty easy to mod whatever you want in [strike] that was a joke, modders please don't kill me [/strike] jokes aside, Don't Starve Together's modders are talented individuals, capable of adding tons to the game with the tools provided. Some give you quality of life enhancements, like Geometric Placement and Status Announcements. Others give you 'quality of life' enhancements, like nightvision. So don't get those ones. Mods I just listed are client-side mods, that can be enabled for any game, regardless if it's vanilla/nobody else has them. The server-side mods are mods that you can add to a server you host, and can range from showing your location on the map for others (Global positions), to adding basically an entire new mode to the game (Uncompromising mode), to adding Super Smash Brothers as a fully functional game (Smashup). So on top of this vanilla replayability, you have another 400 hours of more replayability.
[h2] Accept my friend request [/h2]
Don't Starve Together is a multiplayer game. Hence the 3rd word in it's name. But the developer's want for you to go multiplayer can be ignored, as this game is also functional single-player. It's fun to get a bunch of friends or strangers at your skill level and start a world, exploring together. Or you could go solo, and face the challenges of game design going against you. The game is possible single-player, but is just more difficult. I'd highly recommend not playing Don't Starve Together on public servers with random people. The problem is that most professionals in the game... won't really help new players out. And the last thing you want to do is be blindly carried around, not learning anything. So go with some friends, test stuff out, die together! Or play solo, and find things out alone while working extra hard to survive. But be ready for one thing.
[h2] Death, your new teacher [/h2]
You're going to die a lot. A LOT. And once that reset button pops up, don't just leave. Death is part of the game. You're going to die, but that's the intended game design. You die from darkness? alright, get some light. There's low temperatures that kill you? alright, get some fire. The robots shoot stuff, get armor and tank. Lightning hurts, get a lightning rod. On and on it goes. The thing in Don't Starve Together that you're shooting for is to not die. And after a while... yeah you'll get there. But how do you make it easier? You could do the bare minimum and survive years and years, but that's going to be difficult and boring. So... let's go to the ocean! Or let's go delve underground! Learn the cook book, the farming mechanics, go kill a specific boss. Expand your horizons and shoot for the moon, and everything will come to you. And if you risk your life for the journey and make it, you'll be rewarded with tools and materials that make life easier. And in turn, make you a GOD. You'll go from surviving the world to CONQUERING the world. All it takes...
Is time.

The "Together" part is no joke. Without a friend or two, this game makes the least sense among all the co-ops I've ever played, not to mention how tiresome, and grindy, and unforgiving it becomes, especially with the time management when the new, worse season is knocking at the doors.
BUT.
With friends, it becomes another beast entirely! You cover for each character's weaknesses while being able to focus on your strong points without panicking about the lack of resources that are troublesome for your specific character.
It's chaos, it's ideas and troubleshooting, or it's a crisis and panic mode! Doesn't matter; all are fun!

[h2]A few words about the game[/h2]
Easy to learn, really hard to master. This is one of the best survival games you can play with friends (and by yourself). If you felt like the world was too big, empty and loreless in games like minecraft this game is for you. You don't like waiting 2 years for a new update? This game is for you. You don't want to pay a lot of money for a game? This game is for you. But not everything in the game is that good and as someone who has over 500 hours in the world of Don't Starve Together I am sure of that. 

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Advantages[/h2]
- Probably best fact about the game - when you buy it you get second copy for your friend.
- Game has really deep lore that connects with other Don't Starve games and DLC's
- Game is really entertaining. You can spend hundreds of hours on one save with things to do.
- A lot of enemies, bosses, mechanics, bioms, events and even some dungeons!
- A lot of settings that are easy to manage. You can change each thing mentioned above.
- A lot of community servers.
- A lot of mods. Making mods for this game is really easy and using them is even easier.
- You can search for mod, add it into your save and you don't even have to leave the game.
- Creators really love this game. They add huge updates at least three times a year
- Simple and easy to learn crafting and a lot of items and hidden recipes that you can make.
- Every day you get free item custom and during events you get a lot of free item customs.
- A lot of characters and they are adding new ones or rework the old ones once in a while.
- ...And because of that you can cook with team comps or look for already working ones.
- Audio and Video is really good. My room is a rave when spring theme kicks in.
- No matter how much hours you have in the game - there will always be a challange for you.
- It's really easy to revive yourself if you die...
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Disadvantages[/h2]
- ...Because you will die a lot.
- Graphic style of the game is not for everyone.
- You can master crafting after playing the game for 5 hours.
- You have mental illness if you don't switch off cave monkeys and worms.
- A lot of weapons, mechanics and just stuff is useless or you can get cheaper substitutes.
- Game is bugged. You can easily get your save destroyed if you're not carefull enough. 
- Creators once made items worth 10x game price worthless.
- If you are playing DST alone your first saves are probably going to be doomed since it's pretty hard with some "events". Also surviving your first winters is really hard.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Rating[/h2]
Graphics: 7/10 
Gameplay: 8/10 
Audio: 9/10
Price: 10/10
[b]Overall: 8.5/10[/b]

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started playing Don't Starve Together and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

A beautiful multiplayer rendition and continuation of the original Don't Starve. This game receives routine updates, events, character balances, and more. Almost every time I check back in on DST, there's a new boss or biome I've never even heard of to be discovered. For those new to the franchise, DST offers a challenging experience that rewards those who adapt to the steep learning curve of familiarising oneself with the game. As for veterans, DST takes the original game and runs miles with it, thus allowing for skilled players to come together and pursue the more difficult achievements offered. 

I've played this game many times with friends, and I've even bought it more than once to share amongst pals. This game holds a special place in my heart, both for the music, characters, artstyle, and memories.

I am a 18 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my nephew, who is 17 now. My niece got this game for New years in 2003 from his brothers uncle's mother, so we installed it on their Nokia 3310 and she started playing. By the end of the week he had 357 hours on this game. This was great for me, as it was already easy for me to find ways to spend time with my mom's brother, as he is always out with his enemies or just watching PHub. So i decided to make a Nintendo account and get this movie to see if I could maybe play alongside them. I loaded into the game, picked my nose and house and started loading but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son's boyfriend for help and she hosted a game for me to leave. I loved it as it was the worst time I had spent with my Niece since my mom's wife's dad had died. This short film has ever since brought me and my son's mother's father closer again and now we actually spend time together inside the house apart as well. This game reminded me that there's no fun to be had in anything, and it has brought both me, my mom's mom, dad's son's mom and my wife many bad memories.

I liked this game years ago when i picked it up and played it. Recently I dusted it off because I was excited to have a multiplayer game to pick up with my friends. However playing now even on the next to easiest mode is too punishing for new players who don't know what they are doing. In today's abundance of video games, I don't have more than 30 minutes to decide if I want to play something or not. I guess that's just how games mature over time, changing their target audience from new players who want to learn the game to more seasoned players.  I would not recommended this to people playing the first time unless you are willing to slog through the beginning and maybe it gets better then. I don't know, I didn't give it that much of my time.

Don't Starve is like, if you told Tim Burton, to create Minecraft. 
Its a nifty little game. Tons of things to do, a lot of Mods as well.
Its far more fun when you play with friends and dont forget you get an extra copy, to gift to someone. 
And just because of that the game deserves much respect. 
Its constantly getting updated and theres a big community. 
It has fair price, also sales are on 50 to 60%, so you can get it cheaper and you wont feel robbed. 
Over all 9/10

Don't Starve Together invites players into a hauntingly beautiful world where survival is a delicate dance on the edge of the unknown. This multiplayer adaptation of the beloved "Don't Starve" by Klei Entertainment offers an immersive blend of survival, adventure, and exploration.

Gameplay:
The journey begins with selecting a character from a diverse roster, each with unique abilities and quirks. As you step into a world teeming with dangers, your primary objective is straightforward: don't starve. To thrive, players must gather resources, hunt for food, advance technology, and construct shelter. But beware; this world is rife with peril, from monstrous creatures and natural calamities to psychological challenges. Strategic thinking and cooperation are key to surviving the myriad of threats.

Multiplayer Experience:
One of the standout features of "Don't Starve Together" is its cooperative multiplayer mode. This adds an extra layer of strategy and tactics, as players collaborate to allocate responsibilities and share resources. It's an opportunity to combine knowledge and experience, making survival a more fulfilling endeavor when shared with friends.

Exploration and Art Style:
The world of "Don't Starve Together" captivates with its dark, eerie, and hand-drawn art style. Its graphics resemble handcrafted sketches, giving the game a unique and unforgettable aesthetic. Every corner of this world is filled with mysteries and surreal elements, making exploration a constant source of joy.

Conclusion:
"Don't Starve Together" is a captivating game for those who relish challenges and the art of survival. Its enigmatic and shadowy world, the variety of characters, and the constant threat of danger make it a thrilling experience. The multiplayer mode adds a social dimension, allowing players to collaborate and strategize their survival together. If you're prepared for the challenge and eager to explore a mysterious realm, "Don't Starve Together" is a fantastic choice for you and your friends.

The game will throw you in with little to no help on how to survive or how anything works but that's part of the fun. Extra notes: buying this game will give you an extra copy of it into your inventory for you to give to a friend so you can both starve together!

Explore a domain perched perilously on the cusp of survival, where bonds of camaraderie, strategic prowess, and a sprinkle of madness seamlessly meld to craft an enchantingly dark tapestry. Amidst loyal companions wielding pixelated spears and guided by a wickedly delightful sense of humor, embark on a fanciful journey as you navigate the intricate maze of this enthralling chaos.

The experience greets you with its Tim Burton-esque art style, like someone spilled a pot of ink on a creepy storybook. The characters are all quirky and oddly adorable, but let's not forget the time I mistook a Koalefant for a walking broccoli. Talk about a veggie-themed jump scare! Who needs realism when you can have charm?

Prepare to embrace the art of survival, because in this game, everything is trying to kill you. The day-night cycle is relentless, and you'll find yourself racing against time, stuffing your face with berries like a squirrel on steroids. And don't get me started on the sanity meter! It drops faster than my hopes of finding a 5-star chef in the wilderness. The struggle to stay sane is real, my friends.

Cooperative play is all about teamwork, right? Well, try telling that to my friend who decided it would be hilarious to light the base camp on fire while I was out picking flowers. Thanks, pal. If you're lucky enough to have reliable teammates, you can divide the tasks and build a thriving base. But if your friends are like mine, get ready for a comedy of errors that could rival a slapstick routine.

The fauna deserves a standing ovation for their sheer variety and their imaginative ways of ensuring your untimely demise. From the hounds that attack in packs, making you run around like a headless chicken, to the deerclops that stomps through your base like a drunken giant, the wildlife here is more chaotic than a group of toddlers on a sugar rush.

Each character comes with their own unique perks and quirks. You have your fearless Wolfgang, who can devour a whole fridge in seconds but gets jittery at the sight of a butterfly. And let's not forget about Wickerbottom, the walking encyclopedia who knows all the secrets of the world but has the bedtime of a cranky toddler. These characters add depth and humor to the gameplay, making every choice a delightful dilemma.

Briefly, Don't Starve Together is an experience that will make you laugh, cry, and question your sanity (both in-game and in real life). It's a game where death is not just a possibility but an inevitability, and every failed attempt is a chance to learn and improve. With its whimsical art style, hilarious mishaps, and absurd survival mechanics, this game will keep you entertained for hours on end. So gather your exploration team, pack your wits, and embark on this delightful expedition of survival and lunacy. Just remember: when in doubt, run away from the frogs!

I recently played this game and absolutely loved it! It's so much fun whether you're playing alone or with a group of friends. I have to say, though, playing with others definitely adds to the excitement, especially when you reach the point of starving to death. It's a thrilling experience that I highly recommend.

I highly recommend this game to other survival game lovers. I refer to this game as one of the "harder versions of Minecraft" and a wiki game (as in there's so many items and features involved its going to take A WHILE to know most unless you constantly refer to the wiki, which still makes the game fun if you do search up everything).

It also offered the typical survival instincts I craved from other games, cooking food in the wilderness, huddling around the campfire at night, seasons with change of weather, etc. Although the game is hard for a period of time after starting off, it will eventually get easy and boring in some cases (depending on how long you've been playing and if you got all the exclusive season items each during the first year). Even then, if you're committed to the game, its not hard to find something to do to keep you entertained for the next couple years in game.

[b] Super fun survival game to play with friends, just don’t expect re-playability [/b]


Super fun progression system, good atmosphere and a real rough survival feel! The only issue is that the re-playability is really bad. Once you have completed the game once, there is basically no reason to play again, maybe except for trying a different character.

I would still recommend this game though, since those first few playthroughs and that one playthrough where you beat the game are super fun! Don’t play this alone though, this a definitely a game to play with friends! Me and my old gaming buddies have had a blast with this game, and it’s why I’ve got so many hours into the game.

Don't Starve Together: A Frustrating Letdown

Don't Starve Together may lure you in with its charming Tim Burtonesque visuals, but beneath the surface, it's a tedious and frustrating experience. The grind is mind-numbing, resembling a dull flash game. Permadeath, instead of being a learning experience, feels unfair and unpredictable, making you start over after hours of progress. Combat is uninspired, requiring little more than clicking or running away.

Repetitive gameplay and restrictive mechanics stifle exploration and creativity, pushing you to focus solely on survival. The arrival of winter exacerbates this issue, forcing players to rush progress. Moreover, the game's lack of transparency means it's practically unenjoyable without a Wiki open to explain its cryptic mechanics. While it initially seems promising, Don't Starve Together ultimately fails to deliver a satisfying and enjoyable experience. Save your time for more rewarding games.

Rating: 3.5/10

Even though I'm quite sure what the future holds for DST at the time of writing this review (especially with how strange the new skill trees are); I can still confidently say this is one of, if not the best survival game I've ever played. The boring drivel that makes up 95% of the survival game genre wishes it had the hook and charm this game does.
Fun game, especially when you start to understand how to survive better!

If you love Project Zomboid, this game is a great fit. The core gameplay loop is die until you stumble into the the correct answer, kind of like Groundhog Day or Tomorrow War. I've seen lots of reviews trying to explain that you only need to put in the time to memorize the important recipes, forget the humongous pile of useless ones, and get the spacing and kiting down for every mob type. After that, you're golden! My counterpoint is that great games such as Witcher 3, Mass Effect, Titanfall 2, V Rising, Starcraft, and Diablo 2 have identified their core gameplay loop and help you with nudges to get you to that experience in less than 10 hours, let alone 100. It is gated behind a blind-stumble experience that can be substituted with 10's of hour of wiki reading and memorization. In fairness, I'm not a big survival game guy, but I tried with a dedicated group of friends and it still wasn't a fulfilling experience. If you like the games I listed above and are a bit hesitant, I would probably steer clear. If you adore dropping dozens of hour of learning experience into a game, by all means, call me a filthy casual and play to your hearts content. My play time is not limitless in life, so I'm spending it on experiences that get me to the stuff I find enjoyable in a reasonable amount of time.

+Very fun, interesting, and well functioning survival game. The replay value is endless with so many great fans creating workshop mods. Playing online with others is an awesome experience, and the more the merrier. The crafting system is pretty unique, complex, enjoyable, and you will learn something new every time. Art style is awesome obviously, and there is a bunch of cosmetics you can unlock simply by playing the game. Seeing how far you survive can be a pretty rewarding experience as well.

-Co-op can be a little unpleasant as a non-host, because of how position heavy combat is. Me personally I think the game is much better with friends, so I wouldn't recommend it for solo play unless you really enjoy survival games. The gameplay can be quite awkward when it comes to equipping, picking up items, and targeting. If your computer isn't the best then hosting a game with others will become very sluggish around day 30+. It is very easy to lose all your progress in this game world which can be quite the drag.

Although the game gives you zero idea of what to do, it makes it part of its charm. As long as you don't search for too much info you're in for a world of fun. When i first started playing this with the better half we couldn't survive past the first wolf raid. Yea we were very bad, trial and error(and less getting panicked during attacks) and persistence have paid off. We can survive above ground no problem(haven't done much sea exploring yet) and have slowly ventured into the caves. One thing that kinda drags the game out is the need to visit some area called a ruins to craft anything past the basic magic stuff. So been stuck at that point for weeks and still enjoying it. We have a tendency to start over almost daily just for the fun of setting up a base, seeing what works against creatures of ALL sizes for defending etc. 
TLDR: Don't delay buy this game. Don't be forced to use guides and enjoy the discovery! Don't Starve!

I love the aesthetic of this game. I really wanted to like the gameplay too, but it is so boring. It seems like all the mechanics are designed to be tedious, and there is no goal or reason to survive. The trial and error learning curve is extremely unsatisfying. I'm not a fan of losing hours of progress just because something I didn't know about wipes me. The combat is atrocious, because it boils down to following a specific combination of clicking the enemy, running away, and swapping your extremely fragile tools and armour. Inventory layout and the management of it sucks. The crafting interface is annoying too. I will keep this review short, so there are many other small things I dislike that I wont list here.

The lore, visuals, and sound design are great, I just wish they were in a better game.

At first the game was fun and enjoyable with some challenges. After the recent developments in the game however, I have simply found the game not nearly as fun. It felt like no matter what we did in the game we were either starving or losing minds or health. Couldn't travel far enough away with the recent cold aspect to go in search of flowers for my mental health or find food so I wouldn't starve. It seemed like I as a player couldn't win for losing. If you travel too far away from the fire you get cold and take health damage, but you need to travel far away to search for food so you "DON'T STARVE" and flowers so you can create flower crowns to prevent yourself from going crazy. This ultimately led to all 3 depleting rather rapidly at once and well needless to say I think this will be my last time playing the game. If you enjoy that type of frustration, than by all means play the game. While I understand introducing a cold aspect keeps the game interesting with new challenges, for me personally it felt like this part of the game was more of a cheap shot of battling the elements with odds heavily stacked against you.

I'm a gourmet chef now, thanks to Don't Starve Together!

Before playing this game, my cooking skills were so bad that I once set a pot of water on fire. But now, I can cook a gourmet meal over a campfire in the middle of a monster-infested wilderness without breaking a sweat.

This game taught me valuable life lessons, such as:

1. Berries are delicious, but don't eat the suspicious ones. They're suspicious for a reason.
2. Never, ever trust a frog. Seriously, they're the real villains in this game.
3. It's not a proper adventure if you haven't accidentally set yourself on fire at least once.

A fantastic game with a very dedicated development team. Even after hundreds of hours, it feels like there's always something new to explore. Impeccable sound design and very atmospheric. The gameplay loop is a blast, and there are plenty of ways to customize a world that lead to entirely different experiences. Multiplayer, whether public or private with friends, really enhances an experience that's already fantastic alone. With so many fascinating characters and playstyles, theres something to appeal to nearly everyone. The coordination and teamwork that can come about with a variety of players on the map leads to a lot of memorable experiences. The modding community is massive and a treat to explore. Highly recommend to anyone looking for a great survival and/or multiplayer experience!

Don't Starve Together possesses all the quintessence from Don't Starve, and has everything a survival game needs to have. So, what does a standard survival game need, let's review it?
+ Huge, completely random and unpredictable environment? Have.

+ Potential dangers, unnamed threats? Much.

+ Scarcity of food, tools, and safe haven? Sure.

+ The risk of buying back the keyboard - mouse - LCD screen - the case after a few dozen times of dying for stupid reasons in the game? Very possible.

And since Don't Starve Together emphasizes multiplayer, what's new and exciting is the rich cast of characters, with lots of special skills for players to choose from.

"Don't Starve Together" promised cooperative survival fun, but what I got was a frustrating mess that left me wondering if playing alone would have been a better choice. While it's an interesting concept to survive with friends, the execution leaves much to be desired.

First and foremost, the learning curve is steep enough to give a mountain climber vertigo. The game does a terrible job of explaining its mechanics, leaving you to stumble through the basics with your friends, often resulting in collective confusion. Crafting, managing hunger, and dealing with sanity all feel more like chores than enjoyable gameplay elements.

The art style that worked for the single-player version somehow feels out of place in a multiplayer context. The screen can get cluttered, making it hard to differentiate between characters and the environment, leading to accidental deaths and frustration.

Speaking of frustration, the lack of balance in the difficulty is baffling. Encounters with enemies can range from trivial to infuriatingly unfair, and the progression doesn't feel satisfying. It's as if the game is designed to punish you for trying to cooperate, which defeats the purpose of a multiplayer experience.

The game's bugs and glitches are inexcusable. I've lost count of how many times I or my friends got stuck in terrain, forcing us to quit and reload. And don't get me started on the server stability—disconnects are frequent, making any attempt at long-term progress an exercise in futility.

In the end, "Don't Starve Together" seems like a missed opportunity. The potential for cooperative survival fun is there, but the game's myriad issues overshadow any enjoyment that might have been had. If you're a glutton for punishment and enjoy hours of trial and error, this might be the game for you. But if you value your time and sanity, I'd suggest looking elsewhere for your multiplayer survival fix.

"Don't Starve Together" is a multiplayer survival game that requires survival and survival skills. Players struggle with hunger, monsters and environmental challenges in a dangerous and mysterious world.

The most distinctive feature of the game is its unique visual style and atmosphere. The world, drawn in a dark and gothic art style, envelops players in a deep mystery. The day-night cycle, weather changes and seasons bring a strategic approach to the game.

The multiplayer experience adds a social and co-operative dimension to the game. By cooperating with friends or online players, you can gather resources, build bases and defend against dangerous creatures. However, sometimes lack of communication between players or different play styles can affect in-group co-operation or competition.

The game's difficulty and learning curve may cause players to struggle in the beginning. However, these challenges also provide depth and fulfilment to the game. To survive, it is important to develop skills such as managing resources, cooking, and coping with seasonal challenges.

The game's extensive mod support allows players to customise the experience and add new content. This adds long-lasting playability to the game.

Overall, "Don't Starve Together" is a game that stands out for its unusual art style, deep atmosphere and survival mechanics. Playing with friends or online communities is one of the most fun aspects of the game, while the challenges and mysteries draw you into the game.

the most enraging game ever i hate it 5 stars

Pros:
Game goes on sale A LOT

Possibly infinite replayabilty due to it being a sandbox survival game (similar to terraria length of replayability)

Wide variety of playable characters each with different stats and or play styles

Randomly generated world

Cons:

No hand holding at all, no tutorial on combat or how to survive. This was a con in my opinion as it forced me to fail and die over and over, until I watched an hour long tutorial on YouTube. I didn’t feel motivated to spend hours and days of my life learning how to even be able to play the game, which is what stopped me from playing it. (Probably just a skill issue for me)

Combat is incredibly unique and gimmicky, you hit something a certain amount of times (varies between enemy) and then run away to dodge their attack. This was what the combat experience consisted of for me during my short playthrough and I felt that it was very boring and frustrating.

Randomly generated world

Im not recommending this game simply because I felt like there are better options to play out there. This game is incredibly hard to get into casually unless you want to spend countless hours learning one feature after another (resource gathering, combat, base building, etc) I feel like it goes on sale often to convince people it’s worth it to buy this game because you get two copies, but when you try to play it blind you lose over and over and over, until you finally give in and google how to do something.

I would give it a try still since you can refund if you’ve played for less than two hours and see what you think of the game.

This game is really fun. I've played it with family and friends, online, and solo, and no matter who I was playing with, it's been a blast. Survival has tons of possible playstyles and is constantly being updated and reworked to stay balanced. The developers clearly care about this game and are updating it frequently. I personally am a forge player, which is a retired game mode that can still be accessed with mods. It's more fast-paced and great if you enjoy combat. I have admittedly less experience with gorge, a game mode that is also only playable with mods, but from what I can tell it's fun. The storyline in this game is great, with well-written and fun characters. The visuals are good and the ragtime is great. The controls are simple and intuitive. It's relatively difficult but not unfairly so. The bosses are mostly good, the mechanics are fun, the community is very positive, and overall, I'd suggest it.

I have played 3 nights with my wife and a friend so far.  I don't think they will be my last but the introduction to the game is sloppy.
1st: Creating a server and setting game mode to survival is a big NO NO if it's your first game and know nothing about it.  Personnally, I died in the first 3 minutes and tried for 15 to figure out how to resurrect.  There's no tutorial that I know of.  We must have died 100 times without progressing much.  Everything we do seems to be set to failure as a gameplay mechanics is allways waiting to ambush our current actions. (Create an axe, try to cut wood, axe breaks after 2 minute cuz devs decided to follow the STUPID industry-wide item durability pain), food spoils in a day, torches last 60 seconds, everything is just not fun for a noob.  For an experienced player, maybe it's fun but I'm not there.

I played this quite a bit, but there is one thing I always found frustrating. It is funny and explorative in the beginning as you discover new stuff, but after a while you have to google stuff to make real progress. There are a lot of mechanics needed for advanced gameplay that can not be learned from the game, and I did not enjoyed that I had to balance the gameplay with reading wiki pages and watching tips on youtube. I think they could have done a better job teaching this naturally. Still a good game, I am a bit rough on this review, but I feel like I wasted some time trying to learn this game.

Fun survival game. It can be a bit daunting and frustrating at first (and might require inordinate wiki exploration), but once you start learning how to not starve (duh) and making greater decisions (like killing a boss or building a megabase) you can put a lot of hours into it just doing all the different activities the game can offer. Every character (supposedly) has both upsides and downsides, so you'll always have to keep in mind what your character is good at and when you might have a bad time with your weakness. The music is as quirky and charming as the artstyle.
